Dear Sir:

Re 14 wash basins fixed in boy's & girls wash rooms in basement

Replying to your letter of December 4th we have gone into the matter of soap dishes and toilet paper holders, and have pleasure in quoting you as follows:-

12 N.P.Soap Dishes fitted to Iron frames and attached to the Batteries of Basins in Boy's & Girl's Lavatories.

Birtle, Manitoba,
January 20th, 1931

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Re boys & Girls Wash Room Basins.

These 14 basins are back to back but four inches apart in the centre. No soap dishes are called for and no provision made for same. This matter re soap dishes. Principal Curry, Mrs. Curry and Mr. Lazenby have mentioned several times to me about this. I note also that in toilets that no waste paper holders for same are called for, also that no soap dishes for other other baths throughout the building. I asked Contractor to submit an estimate for supplying and drilling and fastening paper holders to panels. Enclosed please find a copy of contractors price for $213.00. I submit same for your approval.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

David Henderson,
Clerk of Works.
January 28th, 1931.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.

Gentlemen:-

If you will please be good enough to let us have your check to cover at an early date, we can assure it will be appreciated.

Very truly yours,

WALLACE & TIERNAN LIMITED

Dear Sir,

We beg to quote you a price of $150.00 for six galv. iron ventilators installed in each of barns to correspond with those already in, and cutting openings and installing twelve louvre outlets. These outlets are Beatty fixtures, damper controlled by chain to open or closed as desired. Also cut opening and put in damper in frame ventilator above loft floor so that present system may be closed off.

Yours truly,

H. M. DOIG

Per [signature]
Birtle, Manitoba,
February 5th, 1931.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Re Cow & Horse Barn.

In reply to yours of January 29 Re Ventilation of these barns. Enclosed please find estimate submitted by Contractor Doig to put this work in hand for the sum of One Hundred & Fifty Dollars for six galvanized iron ventilators to be fixed at floor level on outside of frame. He quotes for these to be done in galvanized iron similar to the others also to put in a damper a foot above the hay loft door which can be opened or shut if we should wish to use them in Summer. The new ventilators will be outside of frame and operated with a chain to open and shut.

This I forward for your consideration and approval.

Your obedient servant,

David Henderson,
Clerk of Works.

Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sirs,

We completed our contract re Barns at Birtle Industrial School, including priming coat of paint, by Dec. 31st, 1930. We have two coats of paint to apply yet. For best results this should not be done until the weather warms up in the spring. We have received our last estimate, but with our deposit and 10% holdback on estimates we have about $2665.50 still owing to us. We have allowed $500.00 for painting. Would it not be possible for you to hold back this amount and let us have cheque for balance. We do not like to press this matter, but the financial situation in the West, this year, is terrible, and we need this money badly. We believe Mr. Henderson confirmed this matter to you in a previous letter.

Anxiously waiting your action in this matter, we beg to remain,

Yours truly,

H. W. DOIG
Birtle, Manitoba,

Principal's Residence.
Re archway from hall into living room.

February 4, 1931.

Sir:

I have for reply your letter of January 13th enclosing accounts which have been forwarded you by the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Neepawa, for Mr. W. H. Dalton for work done at the Birtle Indian School.

I am enclosing a statement of account submitted on behalf of Mr. W. H. Dalton, Neepawa, for work done at the Birtle Indian School and prepared in this office. I also desire to refer you to the statement of account forwarded to you under date of December 15th last. You will observe that both statements show a balance due to Mr. Dalton of $82.83. In comparing these statements with the one forwarded you by the Canadian Bank of Commerce, on behalf of Mr. Dalton, you will please note the following differences:

Time Sheet No. 1 as originally submitted by Mr. Dalton, totalling $477.65, and after deducting his own time of eighty-five hours at $1.60 per hour there was left $320.35, not $410.35 as shown on Mr. Dalton's statement. Apparently Mr. Dalton has only deducted twenty-five hours for his own time on this pay sheet whereas he should have deducted eighty-five hours. This error makes a difference of $99.00 between the two statements—this amount being $90.00 difference plus 10% profit figured by Mr. Dalton on the $90.00 not deducted.

Time Sheet No. 2 is in agreement on both statements.

Time Sheet No. 3 differs by $2.00—this being an overcharge on Mr. Dalton's statement covering 136 meals at .40¢, whereas his receipt from Claydon Company only shows 131 meals at .40¢.

Mr. Dalton's statement shows $262.50 for his own time, whereas our statement shows this should be increased to $264.37. All other items on the statement are correct.

A. E. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
The Canadian Bank of Commerce, Neepawa, have enclosed an account of Claydon Company Limited for $115.15. Our information is that this account has not been paid, and accordingly should not be included in the statement giving the amount due Mr. Dalton. The fact that it has not been paid is not the fault of Mr. Dalton but is due to objections on behalf of this office to two or three of the items listed on the account. The matter of the settlement of this account is being taken up with Claydon Company by this office and when an agreement has been reached, Mr. Dalton will be authorized to make payment, after which you will be requested to forward an additional cheque to Mr. Dalton in final settlement of his account. In the meantime I would request that a cheque for $382.63 be forwarded to the Canadian Bank of Commerce at Neepawa for the account of Mr. W. H. Dalton for full settlement of his account for work performed at the Sirtle Indian School with a single exception of the amount involved in the account outstanding with the Claydon Company Limited.

Your obedient servant,

Acting District Chief Engineer.

Enclosure.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a statement of account of the General Supply Company of Canada for the installation of the Filtration Plant in the Birtle Indian Residential School.

The quotation given by the General Supply Company of Canada was for One International 48", Style "B" Pressure Filter, F.O.B. Winnipeg; the price to be $475.00. To this must be added the extra freight from Winnipeg to Birtle, amounting to $16.90, or a total of $491.90. Deducted from this is the amount of $4.71 being a credit note from the General Supply Company covering extra material supplied by this office. The total amount due to the General Supply Company is, therefore, $487.19, and I would recommend the payment of this account.

Two pressure gauges, supplied by the General Supply Company of Canada, have proven faulty and have been returned to them for adjustment or replacement. To date these replacements have not been made. However, it is not suggested that payment of this account should be delayed, pending the replacement of these two gauges.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting District Chief Engineer.

A. E. MacKensie, Esq.,
Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir: Re Black-boards on class rooms.

On visit of Principal Curry he has remarked that they have not sufficient black boards in these class rooms. I find that he requires one black-board twelve feet long to be placed on North side of girl's class room and on the long wall in boy's class room dividing between class rooms, one on each side. An early reply to this and your approval will oblige and I will ask contractor to submit an estimate on same on receipt of your letter and save delay.

February 9th, 1931.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Principal Curry will be pleased to have
a single panel door leading from his hall into
living room in place of two doors written for on
February 5th. As plan only shows open arch be-
tween living room and hall. I enclosed price of
$67.00 for two doors as Mrs. Curry wanted them
but I have taken up this matter with them since
and they will be quite satisfied with a 3' x 7'
door. As plasterer is here from Winnipeg to do
patching etc and is about finished it was necessary
for me to order part of this arch to be studded and
plastered up to suit a 3' x 7' door, before plasterer
goes away. I await your approval to put this door
in so that I can order contractor to order door.

Your obedient servant,

David Henderson,
Clerk of Works.
Birtle, Manitoba,
February 9th, 1931.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I have just received contractor Claydon's Progress Statement No 7, and the following item to metal angle beads and vertical angles to window jambs, the contractor has quoted the sum of $620.00. I asked the contractor to quote prices for ordinary metal angle beads and also a price for bull-nose beads and received approval from the Department for the ordinary metal angle beads. Having sent the original contractor's price to you without keeping a copy I would be pleased to know if the sum of $620.00 he charges refers to ordinary beads or Bull-Nose angles. I have a feeling that $620.00 was quoted for Bull-Nose beads and a sum over $400.00 for ordinary angles. I would be pleased to hear by return mail if the sum of $620.00 is right for ordinary angle beads so that I can check estimate. I wrote on the 3rd of Nov. and asked you to send me a copy but have had no reply. I am anxious to check over Progress Statement.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

David Henderson,
Clerk of Works.

DH/MC
Birtle, Manitoba,
February 10th, 1931.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir: Re Electric Fixtures.

The electrician has drawn my attention that no lamps are specified for these fixtures. The sum of seven hundred dollars ($700.00) was laid aside for fixtures but no lamps specified or whether they are to be 40 or 60 watt.

I shall be pleased to hear if the Department supply their own lamps. I have the feeling that the seven hundred dollars ($700.00) for fixtures covers this matter but they differ. I shall be pleased to hear at an early date re this matter.

Specification calls for Door Bell on Front Entrance, one in Kitchen and one in Staff Dining Room. Principal Curry would like one at his Main Entrance and one at rear entrance. This I leave for your discretion.

Your obedient servant,

David Henderson,
Clerk of Works.

Re-Indian Residential School at Birtle, Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

We have just finished the Plumbing and Heating in the above Residential School at Birtle, Manitoba, our contract being with Messrs Claydon Co., Limited, and as we were about settling up, they charge us for excavating for drains inside the building, and as there may be a misunderstanding about the specification regarding this, we would be greatly obliged if you would give us your decision on this.

On page 14 of the General Specifications paragraph 2., Excavation, reads as follows:

"Excavate to the depth, form and size shown on foundation and section drawings, or as required, for all basement walls, foundation walls, footings and drains inside the building, to the depth shown and required."

When estimating on this job, we took this paragraph to mean that the General Contractor was to excavate for all our drains inside the building, and did not allow anything for it, and when going over our accounts, Mr. Claydon says that this paragraph means excavating for the Weeping Drains only, and not for the Plumbing drains.

There is nothing in the Heating Specification about the Heating Contractor supplying radiator connections for temporary heat, but in the General Specification it calls for radiators connected up for temporary heat, and we did this as soon as building was ready and moved the radiators to suit the conditions of building, and did not make any charge, so we think it is up to the General Contractors to do the excavating for drains.

We would greatly appreciate getting your decision on this, which will settle up any dispute between ourselves and Claydon Co., Limited. Thanking you in anticipation, we are, yours very truly,

BALLANTYNE & WETMORE LIMITED
Per W.R. Wetmore, Pres.

Re Wash Basins Etc.

Replying to your letter Re Soap Dishes Etc. I wrote Mr. Stead and Mr. Dalton re this matter and had a visit of Mr. Stead a week ago. I have received his estimate and forward same for your approval.

Mr. Dalton quoted me for expensive brass etc. and I wrote to him for other prices and when I receive same will forward on to you.

I also bring the matter before you re Filter Tank, High Pressure Tank, Galvanized piping etc. constructed by Mr. Stead, which was ordered by Mr. Gow. These two tanks have had one coat of paint before they came here and I think one could on tanks will be simple but galvanized pipes will need two coats of Black Japan. Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 2nd instand we have gone over the various items with our sub-contractors, and wish to report as follows:

On the toilet partitions instructions have been issued to the painters to give these two coats of paint.

Re: metal doors to corridor, Messrs McDonald Bros. advise us that they have followed what has been standard practice on four or five other Indian Schools for which they have had sheet metal and roofing contracts.

In order to arrive at what hardware was actually required, it was taken up with the Department, and as these doors were considered as exit doors, it was decided to use push and pull plates on both doors. These having been used on other buildings, they installed the same on the Birtle School.

If it is necessary to put on lock sets, it will also be necessary to put on bolts on one door in which case the push and pull plates and the check on that door would not be required. It is obvious that these will cost more than lock and two bolts, and it is, therefore, not a question of saving money which made them use the two checks and push and pull plates on both doors.
We feel they have made the best interpretation possible of the specification, and trust that in view of the explanation given it will meet with your approval, and would appreciate your advising us by wire as to your decision.

On the matter of painting for the metal doors, we are arranging to have this done, as it is obviously required, but it is not definitely covered in the painting or the door specifications. Our painting sub-contractors claim they did not include for it, and in view of this we request that you have an additional order issued for payment of this item.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed is a copy of a letter from Messrs Claydon.

Contractor's Superintendent refused to have this work done. With reference to toilet partitions, Painter refused to paint these partitions, although specified to receive three coats after being installed, without a written order from Claydon. I wrote Claydon two letters and sent a wire to instruct his Superintendent to have this work done. Now according to this letter they have made up their minds to do this work. I would like to state that they informed me that the partitions got three coats of Duco paint, put on with a spray and they said this was all the work they were going to do. This I would not accept, so now he has arranged to paint these and it will be up to him to send his painter back to do so.

Re Metal Doors.

This work also has been done with a spray. Doors were hung before plaster came. I may state that it is nothing but a prime coat on these doors. These are fire doors leading from corridor to staircases. These doors are not specified to be painted. It seems to be omitted and should all receive two coats after being installed. These doors I ordered to be taken off, when
plasterers came but they only covered them up with paper and paint has peeled off considerably in different places and should at least receive one coat to cover up exposed bare zinc where paint is off. Claydon Co., now demand an order for additional work for this item as per enclosed letter and refuse to make good these defects. This matter to allow an extra I leave to your judgment.

Mr. Curry noticed, with regards to these metal doors that no hardware with hinges and locks were specified. These doors are hinged to the door check on each door with four finger plates. Mr. Curry wants locks on these doors because he wants to lock children out when they should be in the play grounds to stop them from running through building. I informed him that these were fire doors and it was customary to have finger plates on these doors. I have told him repeatedly that they will not allow these doors to be locked.

You will note as per Claydon's letter that they mention that Messrs McDonald Bros, Sheet Metal Workers, have fitted these doors up similar to what they have done in other schools. I may state that the hardware was chosen and approved by the Architect.

Painters will have to come back to finish toilets and I would also like this matter settled so that it can be done at the same time.

Dear Sir:

Re: Birtle Indian School

We have mailed the Final Account re: the above to Mr. Henderson, and trust that he will shortly issue certificate covering same.

There is one item of the account which Mr. Henderson is not conversant with. We refer to Item #25 which is headed as follows:

"To additional cost of excavation being loading and freight charges on dragline to and from Birtle. Dragline necessary to handle boulders and rock which could not be done by ordinary methods." ....... $787.56

We are asking consideration of this account owing to the extra difficulty which we encountered in making the excavation.

Before tendering on the work we sent our Mr. Mitchell to Birtle to look over the site. He made a small test, and reported the ordinary excavation, and our price was based on same. The exact location of the School was not known, and it so happened where the test was made was not covered by the building.

We found nearly the whole of the site was packed with boulders which could not be dislodged without drilling or power. After trying four and six horse plows we were forced to use power, and accordingly loaded the 40 ton dragline from Winnipeg to Birtle. Our bill for doing so just represents the bare freight charges to and from Birtle and loading and unloading once.

The writer discussed this proposition with Mr. Orr,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6252, File 575-5, part 3)
and Mr. Orr promised to consider it, but remarked that he understood we used the machine on a gravelling contract near to Birtle, apparently thinking this might be a set off against freight charges on the School.

It is true we did use the machine in unloading gravel for a road contract, but it was no advantage for us to do so, and if we had not had it in the vicinity would have used caterpillar and circular scraper, which is usual for that kind of work. This work we usually let by sub-contract at prices ranging from 10¢ to 12¢ per cubic yard. It was no advantage whatever to have the dragline on it, as the moving was so slow, and we had to hire tractors to move our outfit so that our expense with regard to freight was wholly due to the School.

We make the above explanations about the use of the machine for fear it might be thought we were getting a double benefit for it being at Birtle, but we can assure you this was not the case.

We trust you will be able to pass the account as charged, and thanking you in advance, we are,

Sir:

I recently inspected the water supply system at the new Indian School at Birtle in company with Mr. Lazenby, Indian Agent. With the putting into operation of the pressure system, it has been shown that leakage exists at some of the pipe jointings, particularly around the pump and the filter plant. The pump was also observed to be faulty but upon representations being made to them in Winnipeg, by the writer, the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company have readily agreed to replace the pump. The leakage at the pipe connections can, of course, be readily made water-tight and upon the completion of this work the pipe, filter and pressure tank should be painted to prevent any further rusting and erosion.

As I have previously advised your department as to these conditions at the school, I advised Mr. Lazenby, at the time of the inspection, to report the conditions to you. However, I am now in receipt of a letter from him in which he states he had done so and was advised to bring the matter to my attention, inasmuch as the work was installed under the supervision of this office. As you are aware, the installation of the water supply system was let to Mr. H. S. Stead of Neepawa on a cost-plus basis, on instructions received from your department at Ottawa. Mr. Stead was considerably handicapped in carrying out this work by lack of proper equipment and etc., but generally speaking the work was carried out in a satisfactory manner. The worst leakage appears to be in connection with the pipe fittings furnished with the filter by the General Supply Company of Canada and these fittings came ready to assemble, so that no fault can be attached to the work of Mr. Stead insofar as poor pipe threading is concerned. It is necessary to have a competent steam fitter engaged for a day or so to correct any loose pipe connections around the filter and the pump and as Mr. Lazenby is at Birtle, and is now responsible for looking after the structure, I would recommend that you instruct him to engage a pipe fitter to fix all leaking connections and also make arrangements for having the necessary painting carried out and to supervise this work. If it is possible to so arrange I would suggest that Mr. Lazenby have Yates-Heale and Company of Brandon, send a man to make the adjustments to the pipes and that Mr. Lazenby make arrangements to have the painting done by local labor. Yates-Heale and company made a very good job of the water installation at the Brandon Indian School and I am sure would fix-up this system at Birtle in a very satisfactory manner.

I must admit answering the letter hurriedly with respect to the electrical fixtures, and quite unintentionally overlooked the explanation asked for with respect to Item 4.

This item is made up of additional excavating and concrete done to the order of Mr. Swan and comprises an extra 4" of width on the footings as shown on separate account attached. Mr. Swan ordered the matter direct from Mr. Mitchell, and for your information we attach copy of letter he wrote us under date of August 26, 1920.

With respect to the details of cost of the electrical fixtures, we enclose herewith copy of letter received from the Levvy Electrical Co. of April 27th. These details were requested from them in the expectation that I would see you before you left our district. We did not receive it from Mr. Levvy, however, until the Monday after you left so the opportunity was not afforded to make an explanation in regard to it.

We checked the prices named on the letter with the wholesaler and found them corroborated. You will notice Mr. Levvy mentions a margin over and above net cost of 15/10%, and makes reference to it as being approved by the Public Works Dept., Province of Manitoba. We find this is also correct and is a standard charge in Manitoba in dealing with fixtures and other electrical work.

In support of the above Mr. Levvy also refers us to
The Secretary of International Association of Electricists
c/o R.A.L.Gray Co., 157 King St.West, Toronto and McCuaig Co.Ltd.,
1252 McGill College Ave., Montreal

The reason the above addresses are given is because Mr. Levy does not know the address of the Secretary, and if you see fit to write to him think it would be as well to send a line also to whichever Company you send the letter to requesting that they forward any inquiry you care to make to the Secretary.

You will notice the Levy Electric letter only accounts for $425.00 whereas the credit of $225 from the $700.00 allowance for fixtures leaves a total of $475.00 as chargeable on fixtures, thus making a difference of $50.00 between the Levy letter and the invoice sent you. The $50.00 is made up by there being sent to Birtle an additional 15- #9104/703 Gill Hyperion Units @ $2.60, a total of $39.80.

In addition to the above there are several other items of work which Mr. Levy claims they should be paid for which amount in all to about $35.00, making a total with the additional fixtures of $68.80. They were the subject of disagreement between Mr. Levy and Mr. Henderson and also a conflict of interest with respect to work of the plasterers. As some of the alleged additional work had been cancelled, the matter was decided to be dropped by allowing the Levy Electrical Co. $50.00 being $33.80 for the regular charge for the additional fixtures and the balance a compromise amount to settle the outstanding differences.

You will understand our position as General Contractors was often very difficult owing to the situation at Birtle, and we had a lot of trouble on our own account in the same way. Several items of work were cancelled and even the additional hardware asked for by Mr. Currie was sent to Birtle by express for which we received no payment and then the hardware had to be returned also at our expense.

We trust the information tendered above will satisfy your inquiry.

In general, we are disappointed to find an account the size of ours, which has been held so long through no fault of ours, should be held up for payment by an inquiry which has to do with such a small amount as the items mentioned herein. We certainly would appreciate having had payment in full of the contract even if you kept the additional items as the subject of inquiry.
In addition to the above we still have the outstanding charge against Mr. Stead and Mr. Dalton of Neepawa on which we cannot get any satisfactory decision with Mr. Gow. We know the accounts rendered to Mr. Stead and Mr. Dalton are in order. In fact have gone into them in great detail since our foreman returned to Winnipeg and are convinced that he erred on the side of leniency, especially as we found we lost $1,000 in running our camp proving that we charged too little for board.

There is no question but what the sand we charged for was destroyed. It was plowed around by horses and so much clay got into it that the amount we charged Mr. Gow has been destroyed.

Furthermore, our lumber was used without our leave for heating sand and gravel. Our foreman on more than one occasion found some of the men chopping up 4 x 4s and 2" dimension lumber for this purpose. Until Mr. Gow raised this contention the account was quite agreed between us, and now we are being asked for minute details on lump sum items which were perfectly agreed between our foreman and Mr. Stead and Mr. Dalton.

Except for the portion of the work which we think was deliberately dragged out by Mr. Henderson our contract has been finished now about three months, and we find it quite a hardship to be out of the money for so long a time. If it is at all possible we think some interest should be allowed us for the delay in making progress estimates during the Winter and on the large amount outstanding since the work was completed. We shall be very glad of any consideration which can be offered in this way, and soliciting your kindly attention to the items on which we requested payment, I am,

Sir,

I beg to report that a few days ago, Principal H.B.Curris of the Indian Residential School, called me by telephone and asked me to go to the school as something had gone wrong with the water system. I immediately went to the school and found that the furnace room was flooded with water, and on making an examination with the engineer, it was apparent that a break had occurred in the pipe leading from the pump room to the barns.

I immediately advised Mr Gow at Winnipeg by telephone, and he instructed me to get the pipe dug out, and two men were set to work at once.

On reaching the pipe, it was seen that the filled in earth had settled, taking the pipe with it, and had broken it at the elbow about ten feet from the building where it turns to the barns.

It will be necessary to dig out the pipe from the building to the elbow, and from the elbow the full length of at least one pipe, (probably about 18 feet), along the line to the barns; cut off the broken portion of pipe and put in a new piece of pipe, with a union, and a new elbow.

I have given instructions that when these repairs are completed, the pipe is to be supported on rocks built up on hard earth, before the filling in is done.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Hazenby
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

RE: BIRTLE INDIAN SCHOOL

In response to your letter of September 24th, we made arrangements for our Mr. Mitchell to visit Birtle and check up the items of the alleged defects.

At the time of receiving your letter, Mr. Mitchell was very busily engaged in cleaning up the Arts Building, University of Manitoba, and we were also in the middle of estimating on the Science Building at the same place, so could not break him away immediately. However, he went there last Wednesday, and went over everything with Mr. Lazenby, and brought back a letter from Mr. Lazenby that each item of work had been put in order.

In general, there was nothing serious the matter. In most cases the work was incidental to what might be expected of a new building with one exception, and that was the possibility of some of the concrete stair filling may have got a touch of frost in it. However, this has been made good, and Mr. Lazenby has expressed his satisfaction with what has been done.

Regarding the floor drain, as pointed out in our telegram, there is nothing that we could do to this excepting put in a sump pump. The boiler room sump is very much below the sewer outlet, and no provision was made by those in charge of the sewer arrangement for taking care of it. At Mr. Henderson's direction, we made a cess pit outside the building, and at the same time gave him as our opinion that it was not a good procedure, and that the connection should be made to the sewer.

Apparently there seems to be a little moisture under the floor, although we are at a loss to account for it, and are wondering if there is any leak in the water system at the rear. The drain from the Kelvinator is run through an outside pipe, also directed by Mr. Henderson, and we hardly think it should cause the trouble.

There certainly is more moisture than one would ordinarily expect, and Mr. Lazenby informed Mr. Mitchell that he has to bail out the sump pit every day.

The moisture under the floor is sufficient to have caused a slight settlement of the two 8" I beams supporting the
Chapel floor, and it would appear that the moisture has also affected the setting of one of the boilers. There is a first class footing under the boiler exactly as called for, which is a foot thick, and is in very good shape.

We think that something should be done at once to take care of this moisture, otherwise we are afraid there may be even more settlement, which would probably be of a serious nature.

We suggest, therefore, that a Pemberthy automatic electric driven sump pump be installed or a water driven pump, supply for which could be taken from the water system. If the electric pump is put in, we would suggest the size #2E which has a 1" pipe connection and is driven by ½ H.P. electric motor. This pump would cost delivered at Kirtle about $120.00. The water driven pump would cost about $80.00. We have not had time to get the exact price on it, but this is approximately correct. We cannot very well quote on the labour involved in installing the apparatus, but we would make as economical a job of it as possible.

We would suggest that this be put on the side of the boiler room against the laundry, and the discharge from it taken to the trench underneath the laundry machines. This would cause less cutting of flooring and concrete than any other scheme we could think of. It would mean putting in a new sump pit in the boiler room floor near to the laundry room wall. We would only than have to break through the brick partition wall to connect to the drain. We would suggest that the Kelvinator waste be taken also direct to this pit, and we think then there would be no further trouble about water.

Our Mr. Mitchell believes, and he reports that Mr. Lazenby is in thorough concurrence with him, that the work should be done without delay. We shall be very glad to receive your instructions on the matter, and carry them out to the best of our ability.

Yours very truly,

CLAYDON COMPANY LIMITED

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 24th September, regarding a Mr Thomas Moynes of Birtle, who is asking for compensation on account of an injury received by him while employed as a labourer on the construction of the new Indian Residential School, I beg to report that I have interviewed Mr Moynes himself, Albert John Smith of Birtle, who was an eye witness, Mr J.W.Pratt Barrister, of Birtle, who took statutory declarations in the matter from several individuals, and Dr P.W.Head of Birtle, who attended to Thomas Moynes.

Mr Moynes stated that the accident occurred on the 8th October 1930, at about 10.30 a.m. At that time, Mr Moynes was one of several men who were engaged in aligning one of the big steel beams, which they were moving with crow bars. Mr Moynes went in between the beam that they were placing, and one that was already in place to remove some obstruction, and while he was in this position, the beam that was being placed tipped over and caught his right leg above the knee, between it and the other beam. After being extricated, he went on with his work, saying nothing about it, and worked that day until 3 p.m., when he had to stop and go home. The following morning, he went to see Dr P.W.Head, who advised him to return home and put hot fomentations on his injured leg. On the 2nd November, Mr Moynes states, he went into Birtle hospital, and remained there until the 13th November, his hospital bill being $19.75. About a week after the accident Mr Moynes put in a claim for compensation, through the Workman's Compensation Board, making out the papers for this, himself. The Board wrote to Mr Moynes on the 26th November.

November 1930, advising him that his claim had been rejected. On May 23rd 1931, evidently in reply to a plea for further consideration of the claim, the Board again wrote to Mr Moynes, stating that his claim had been given further consideration, but that the decision as outlined in their letter of the 26th November 1930, could not be changed. Again on the 15th August 1931, in reply to a letter written to them by Mr Moynes, the Board wrote to him, and simply gave him a verbatim copy of their letter of the 26th November 1930, in which they advised him that his claim had been rejected. Mr Moynes advises me that he has a wife and three children, the ages of the children being 12, 9, and 7 years respectively.

Albert John Smith of Birtle, who was an eye witness of the accident, stated that Mr Moynes' description of the accident was correct; that the boss of the steel work also saw it happen; that about six weeks or two months after the accident he made several sworn statements in connection with the matter, for Mr J.W.Pratt, Barrister of Birtle; and that Mr Moynes had tried again to get work at the school, but could not hold his end up at it, and had to quit.

Mr Pratt showed me statutory declarations he had taken from several individuals in connection with Mr Moynes' claim, and a Mr P.R.Phillips, Surveyor, of Birtle, had prepared a diagram, designed to illustrate exactly how the accident occurred. Mr Pratt stated that it was his opinion that Mr Moynes, in filling out the claim papers to forward to the Workmen's Compensation Board, had probably bungled the matter.

Dr P.W.Head of Birtle, stated that as a result of the accident, Mr Moynes had sustained a severe bruise, with resultant swelling of the leg, and that he had filled out and signed the necessary papers in connection with Mr Moynes claim for compensation through the Workmen's Compensation Board.

With regard to the statutory declarations taken by Mr Pratt, I may say that these were all practically identical, simply stating how the accident happened.

Mr Moynes himself, is a well advanced
case of T.B. All the family are under nourished, and are in straitened circumstances, and are one of a number of families receiving assistance from the Town in the way of food &c;

With regard to the letters written to Mr Moynes by the Workmen's Compensation Board, I may say that I have before me their letters of May 23rd 1931, and August 15th 1931, but I have not seen their letter of the 26th November 1930. Apparently they did not give the reason for their rejection of Mr Moynes' claim.

Sir,

With regard to your telegram of the 13th instant, regarding water coming into the boiler room at the new Indian Residential School, I beg to say that the delay in my reply thereto, was on account of the fact that your telegram arrived at Birtle just after I had left by car with two Indian patients for Winnipeg hospital, on the morning of the 14th, and was awaiting me on my return to Birtle at 10 p.m. the 15th.

I wired my reply on the morning of the 16th as follows:- "Re your telegram of thirteenth. Water still coming into boiler room since repairs to pipe line. Recommend that Gow investigate soon as possible. My opinion that remedial measures should be taken at once to forestall more serious developments. Mailing further report to-day. Your telegram arrived while absent in Winnipeg."

While I was in Winnipeg, I went to Mr Gow's office to discuss this matter with him, as I had already written him. I was informed however, that Mr Gow had gone to Birtle. On returning to Birtle, my wife informed me that Mr Gow had called at the agency. I went to the school the next morning and asked if Mr Gow had been there, but no one had seen him, and apparently he had not gone to the school. I then sent the above telegram to you, recommending that Mr Gow be requested to investigate as soon as possible.

You will no doubt, by now, have received Messrs Claydon Company's letter of the 10th October, in connection with their remedying of certain defects - at the school -

In their letter, the Claydon Company recommend the installation of a sump pit in the floor of the boiler room, with a drain, to the wall next the laundry, and an electric or water driven pump, to pump the water into the trench underneath the laundry machines, which connects with the main drainage system. I agreed with their Mr Mitchell that this scheme would adequately take care of the water from the boiler room floor, when blowing out the boilers and such like, as the present drain in the floor is of no use whatever. Mr Mitchell informed me that the installation of this sump pit and pump would be much cheaper than putting in a proper drain, with connections to the main drainage system.

The chief difficulty, however, is not water that gets on the floor from above the floor, as from the boilers, but what comes in from outside, through the foundation at the north west corner of the boiler room, through cracks in the floor itself, and through the drain in the floor. At present, over 100 pails of water are carried out every day, having to be dipped out of the drain with a tin can. Every morning, the ash pits under the boiler fires are full of water, and the engineer is compelled to wear rubber boots until the water is carried out.

From this, I should judge that the ground under the boiler room floor is by this time thoroughly soaked with water. If this is so, there is danger of further settlement of the boilers and the two columns supporting the chapel floor above, which would develop into serious and costly trouble. I am practically certain that the source of the trouble is in the sump pit which takes the excess water from the chlorinator. This however, will no doubt be decided if Mr Gow comes.

Dear Mr Lazenby:

In connection with the seepage into the boiler room being experienced at the Birtle Indian School, I am in receipt of a telegram from our Ottawa office reading as follows:

"Indian Department request that you proceed to Birtle Indian School at once to investigate and report on cause of seepage in boiler room. Stop. Please take action accordingly."

The writer does not consider that any further investigation is necessary, personally, as it is apparent that the seepage is caused by the overflow from the sump into which the chlorinator drains. There will be, however, a certain amount of seepage into the boiler room from natural causes inasmuch as there is no drainage from the boiler room and under the circumstances none can be provided except by direct pumping.

To overcome seepage from the chlorinator sump, two proposals are now being considered. One proposal is that a drain be constructed from the overflow from the chlorinator around the building to connect up with the laundry drain outside the building and inasmuch as the laundry drain by passes the septic tank no ill effects would be caused the septic tank. Another proposal is that the chlorinator at present installed in the school be replaced by a chlorinating system using liquid chlorine thus doing away with the necessity of having any chlorinating substance whatever. This type of chlorinator would be about $500.00 cheaper than the present type installed but the maintenance charges would be somewhat higher, although the action is automatic as is the case with the present chlorinator.

I have been unable to get in touch with Mr Lindsten of Wallace and Tiernan Limited, but hope tomorrow to take up with him the question of whether this different type of chlorinator will give satisfactory service at the Birtle School, and if so, it may be preferable to remove the present chlorinator, and install a different type. As soon as I have taken up this question with Mr Lindsten, I will prepare a short report outlining the two proposals and forward a copy to your Ottawa Office and also a copy to yourself.

Insofar as the natural seepage of ground water into the boiler room is concerned, this is something that cannot now be overcome because the boiler room floor is only a few inches higher than the outlet to the laundry drain and it would be necessary to construct a new drain from the boiler room to the low ground near the outlet from the septic tank. However, this phase of the situation will also be covered in my report.

Yours truly,

Signed:
D.B. Gow
Acting District Chief Engineer

Sir:

At the new Indian School at Birtle, trouble is being experienced from ground water seepage into the boiler room, causing considerable inconvenience and also causing settling of the floor and foundations. The natural ground seepage is augmented by overflow from the sump provided for caring for the drain from the chlorinator system.

My information is that the floor of the boiler room is at elevation 1690.00, the footings of that portion of the building are at elevation 1688.50 and that the drains laid to provide drainage, lead to a sump under the boiler room floor. No provision was made to discharge this drainage through the general drainage of the school system. As the boiler room is nearly four feet lower than the main school building, drainage cannot be obtained now through the school system except by pumping.

To provide adequate drainage and protect the boiler room floor and footings, it is considered advisable to lay a new drain from the outlet pipe of the chlorinator system to collect the drainage from this system and also connect up with the drain pipe along the foundations of the boiler room and also the catch basin under the boiler room floor. This drain will connect up with the main drain at the manhole below the septic tank. The drain will consist of four inch sewer pipe laid sufficiently below ground surface to prevent freezing and to a sufficient grade to provide against clogging.

The accompanying sketch plan shows the location of the proposed new drain and the accompanying profile shows the depth of drain below ground level, from its source to outlet.

The following estimate is made of the cost of laying this drain:

I understand that the Claydon Company, Winnipeg, were asked to, and did, submit a proposition to provide drainage of the boiler room by means of an automatic pump that would pump the drainage from a catch basin into the school drainage system. I have no particulars regarding their proposals, but would like to point out that if the drainage from the chlorinator sump is seeping into the boiler room, it is altogether likely that this chlorinated water will have some erosive effect upon the piping of the school drainage system. It was for this reason that the waste from the chlorinator system was not passed into the main drainage system, although elevations were such that this could readily have been done. In my opinion the most satisfactory drainage system for the boiler room portion of the building is the proposal outlined above at an approximate cost of $672.00.

The structure presents a good appearance both from close and distant points, and being not on a natural elevation there ought to be no difficulty about drainage or disposing of effluent from the plumbing system. The ground at the building is stated to consist of boulders with clay, very hard when dry. The site is somewhat less than one-half mile from the Canadian Pacific Railway Depot, and less than one mile from the village by road. A picture postcard of the building is submitted with this report.

A catch basin is centrally located in the basement of main building, and the principal drain passes out in an Easterly direction and turns Southerly to connect to the septic tank which is constructed of concrete with two compartments, respectively connected with siphons. The discharge from septic tank spills over the slope of a ravine. Information is that the surface water caught up in the weeping tile system of the main building was carried by a separate drain placed in the same trench as the main sewer and after passing the septic tank it is connected to the main drain thencefrom before it is discharged over the ravine.

Sectional drawings in the plans for the building show weeping tile drains to be set at level of bottoms of footings both of the main building and of the boiler room section. No investigation was made to discover if these weeping tile drains had actually been placed according to plans, but information was received that those for the main building had been laid on top of the concrete footing courses, thus following an idea usually approved by Contractors, while it was suggested that weeping tile drains for the lower footings at boiler room had not been placed at all.

There is a small concrete catch basin about 12" x 12" x 24-0" deep with iron top, in the floor space at front of the two steam heating boilers. It is stated that this catch basin was put in by the Contractors to provide occasional drainage for the boilers, and that its outlet pipe was carried in a Northerly direction underneath the footings to a dry well filled with stones not far from the building. On lifting the cover of this catch basin it was noted as filled with water right up to the top. It was bailed out to a depth of over one foot but filled up within fifteen minutes, thus indicating failure of the dry well idea as a means for carrying away waste water, also that the absorptive qualities of the soil are low.

For the heating system there are two steam boilers, and at the time of this inspection the floor line at same showed as about two feet lower than the floor line at exterior walls of boiler rooms. It appears as a matter for conjecture if this depression is...
the result of settlement or misjudgment in leveling for the concrete bed or foundation of the boilers. The Fall season this year has been dry, and there was no water on the floor of the boiler room at the time of this inspection, but the presence of a watermark up on the sides of the boilers was sufficient to form the idea that such an obstruction in drainage, rainwater entering through roof of coal room, or a broken pipe, after the boilers were erected, the boiler room floor had been covered with water.

Water for use in the School, is obtained by purchase from the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, who get it by pumping from "Bird Tail" Creek, for the principal purpose of watering locomotives at the station. This water is alkaline and being liable to contamination at source, a chlorinating plant has been installed in the School to prepare the water for safe general use. In the operation of the chlorinating plant there is an amount of water used, and it was stated that such water is carried Westerly from the building into a dry well filled with stones. It is understood that arrangements have been made to construct a new drain at good depth for the boiler room section, and that it will be connected up to take the waste from the chlorinating plant. The water, after chlorination, is considered wholesome for drinking purposes, but its degree of alkalinity appears to be unaltered, and therefore it cannot be regarded as altogether satisfactory for cleaning, bathing and laundry purposes, required in this kind of School.

Windows are mostly of box frame type. A few of them however, have casement frames, and it was stated that after the building was regarded as complete the Contractors came back to fasten some of these frames that through oversight had been left insecure as regards setting. One casement window frame in the chapel appears to have been missed in this job of fixing.

Storm sash for the windows are fitted to the inside of same, in divided sections something like casements. This arrangement for storm sash is satisfactory in many respects, but it does not assure the degree of protection from wind that is afforded by storm sash applied externally. If fitted sash to run up and down in box frames, Contractors usually have to consider if the sash ought to be fitted close or open, because it is well known that through the lapse of six months or so the sash may swell or shrink. In this building, completed last March, the sash are now loose fitting; therefore, the wind-resisting qualities of windows are inferior, and for rectifying the situation it might be well to consider the fitting of the main sash with metal window strip.

The rear exterior door to the Principal's residence opens directly into the kitchen from outside, and this doorway is deficient because of the lack of a suitable screen.
screen door or enclosed porch to protect against the weather. A corresponding deflection was noted at the main front entrance doorway to the Principal's residence. Also an opening at the end of the main corridor of the building where it goes to the Principal's residence, is hardly satisfactory in its present condition without a door.

The steel joists in the floor construction above basement, are set at approximately 21" centres. Floors are of concrete two inches thick, carried by "Hyrib" lath and having expansion rods embedded. A finishing coat of cement mixture has been applied throughout to the slabs, excepting the top rows that carry the several sections of roof construction. The ceilings are plaster on metal lath at line of bottoms of joists. It is understood that these steel joists were produced by the Truscon Steel Company of Canada Ltd.

Specifications called for all concrete to be composed of crushed stone, sand and Portland cement, and the use of gravel is distinctly disallowed. Information is that but a small proportion of the concrete was made with the use of crushed stone, and that most of the aggregate was made up with gravel obtained locally. Nearly all of the concrete floors show fine cracks, the presence of which admits of several explanations. There are fewer cracks in basement floor in comparison with the upper floors, and that may be owing to the basement concrete being laid on gravel bed provided, and therefore likely to have greater substance than the two-inch concrete slabs of the upper floors. For the protection of fireplaces concrete of two inches thickness called for in the type of floor construction adopted for this building, the contractor must of necessity exercise the utmost care in every part of the process. The use of gravel in such slabs could only be allowed on the understanding that it should be thoroughly screened and washed, also that the sand should be free from loam and that the water in the mix should be free of alkali if possible. In addition the workman handling the materials must fully realize his responsibility and arrange for the placing of concrete in the most skilful manner and see to it that the setting of poured slabs should be suitably retarded, also that the finish coatings be applied so as not to break the surface of the poured concrete. These details of procedure are well understood by good builders, but there are all too many cases in which the knowledge is unproductive of results. In some cases hardening preparations are used in the mix and in the finish coatings. There is no information if hardeners were used at this building.

The cracks in floors are irregular and not identifiable with any structural settlement, therefore I am of the opinion that they arise from lack of the exceptional care necessary in mixing and applying the concrete.

Although......
Although there are some cracks appearing as having depth the majority are fine, and may be altogether superficial. Some of the deep cracks are possibly at lines of separations dividing the areas in suitable portions for periods of pouring.

The cement floors in corridors are about one-quarter inch lower than the corresponding floors of rooms along same and the edges of these sinkings that show in doorways are irregular. It appears that the difference of levels between the corridor floors and the room floors, had been designed for placing linoleum or other floor covering in the corridors.

In parts of the building the cement floors are giving off dust and edges of larger cracks are breaking away. This process of wearing is likely to become progressive. Painting of floor surfaces with silicate solution is a simple method often productive of good results. There are also paints especially suitable for concrete floors and giving both body and colour when applied on concrete floors.

The plastering of ceilings and walls appears good and no indications of subsidences was noted as regards steel columns. In fact, were it not for the condition of the cement floors, left bare, and resonance to a marked degree, the principal of steel joist construction adopted for the building might be regarded as a considerable advance over ordinary construction.

The chief features observed in this inspection have relation to the drainage of the boiler room, and the condition of the cement floors. There are a few minor items that can be stated, namely:- One place at a door architrave where plaster has broken away; some of the base made of Portland cement does not show good workmanship; at several doors in rooms lined with enamelled brick the bricks over door heads have dropped slightly; exterior brickwork presents a good appearance, although there is considerable variation in the jointing; window sash are mostly loose fitting and draughty, which will result in considerable discomfort and loss of heat; the painting and wood finishing is a fairly good job.

In the absence of definite directions on any particular items to be covered by this inspection, I considered that Mr. Currie, the Principal of the School, could be relied on to draw attention to anything that he would regard as matter for my report. Nothing was mentioned to me about the plumbing installation or fittings, or the steam heating system, and therefore no reference was made to those branches of work, but it appeared that the heating of the Principal's residence, which is located at the far point and Westerly from the boiler room, might prove unsatisfactory in relation to the keeping up of suitable heating

for.......
for the remainder of the building, particularly in consideration of the condition of the windows and exterior doors.

No inspection was made of the roofs, which are flat, and it is likely that they are in very good condition, and have been laid according to specifications. The water from the roofs is taken down inside the building by conductor pipes connected to drains and carried away.

The grounds surrounding the School are in process of improvement. Groupings of shrubbery, trees, flower beds, etc., will undoubtedly make the place attractive after same have attained growth. It had been stated that the plans for these developments are being considered.

The foregoing report concerning the Indian School at Birtle, Man., and comprising five pages additional to this, is respectfully submitted by

Birtle, Man., 14th January, 1932.

Sir:

I beg to forward herewith in duplicate, my report and diary for the month of December 1931.

On the 23rd, while I was at Rossburn, another bad break occurred in the water system at the Birtle Indians Residential school, and in my absence the Principal wired direct to the Department at Ottawa for advice. Mr. D. B. Gow of the Dominion Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau at Winnipeg, was instructed to attend to the matter. On the 24th Mr. Gow telephoned to me, and asked me to supervise the repair of the break. I therefore hired the necessary labour to dig out the pipe line, and in due time, found that the pipe that screws into the main supply tank had broken. This pipe was only screwed in, and holding with two threads. The pipes carrying the water from the C.P.R. tank were also holding by two or three threads in the couplings, and were re-screwed in a further two to three turns. If this is a sample of the work done in the whole of the pipe line, there is no doubt that further trouble may be expected in the future.

Your obedient servant,

P. G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

To test this Sanispray, I have had the boys' recreation room floor at the Birtle Indian Residential School at Birtle treated with it twice. This floor is about 900 square feet in area, and requires one gallon of Sanispray for one treatment, which lasts about two weeks, when another treatment is necessary to properly keep down the dust.

The cost of the Sanispray Oil, is $1.00 per gallon F.O.B.Birtle station, purchased by the 15 gallon drum. The cost may be less than this, of course if a large quantity were purchased. April 15, 1932.

Memorandum

Mr. Bushard,

With reference to the letter from Mrs. McKerrell regarding the outbuildings required for the new Birtle Indian Residential School, I beg to say that last year a cow barn 76' x 32' with silo was erected giving accommodation for 16 single stalls, 4 calf pens, bull pen and feed room. A horse barn 40' x 30' was also erected which provided accommodation for 8 single, 4 double, 2 box stalls, harness room and feed room. Running water was also provided to both these buildings and they were completed in July of last year.

In addition to these two buildings Mr. Currie, the Principal, has asked the Department to provide a sheep pen for 50 sheep, poultry house for 200 hens, root cellar, hog house for 100 pigs, implement shed to accommodate their farm equipment, a garage for one car and truck. If all of these buildings were allowed and erected they would cost approximately $6,000.00.

I am returning Mrs. McKerrell's letter as requested.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that Mr H.B.Currie, Principal of the Birtle Indian Residential School has asked if there would be any objection to his using the class room building at the old school, as a granary, as he has no other place in which to store grain when he threshes the school farm crop this fall.

This class room building was erected in 1924 by the Department, at a cost of approximately $4,000 and is still in very good condition, with the exception of several windows which have been broken since the new school building was erected.

Memorandum:

Mr. Williams,

I am quoting hereunder from a letter received by the Minister with regard to the claim of the Claydon Company, Limited, in connection with their contract for the erection of the Indian School at Birtle:

"In 1930 we built under contract for the Dominion Government an Indian School at Birtle, Manitoba, and in connection with the cleaning up of the account, we feel we have been very unjustly dealt with, and underpaid for some of the work done.

When the tenders were called for, there was no special place on the general site upon which we could be sure the building would be situated, consequently we could not make an accurate forecast of what the excavation would be like. We, therefore, figured the ordinary excavation, which we can generally take out with teams in the country at about twenty-five cents per yard.

After the contract was awarded to us, the definite position of the building was given us, and it was then found that we were excavating on rock and boulders firmly embedded in clay. We began using picks, shovels, and teams, but nothing we could do in this regard made any effect on the work, as it proved impossible to take the excavation cut by any such measures. We were finally driven to ship a forty ton dragline to the site at a cost altogether of unloading and loading of freight of over Eight Hundred Dollars ($800.00). We charged an amount of $787.56 to the Government, which in the final payment was stricken out."
and no explanation given us. The final amount was not paid until last Summer, and until we addressed an inquiry to the Department, we were unaware as to what they had taken from our bill.

Another short payment, as we regard it, was in respect to fireplace in the principal's residence. There was no mention of this in the specification, and excepting for one unexplained portion of the drawing, no indication whatever that a fireplace and mantle was required. Furthermore, electrical and other more or less sham fireplaces are so much used at the present time that we did not feel we were justified in allowing for a regular fireplace.

Although the Inspector on the work was a man who was definitely and admittedly antagonistic to us, the facts were so much in our favour that he was forced to agree with us that if a fireplace and mantle were required, they should be put in at an extra cost, and gave us orders accordingly.

In addition to the work we did ourselves, such as supplying face and hearth brick, we ordered and paid for a special mantle. Our total bill for the work came to $102.21, and we still feel it ought to be paid.*

The Minister would like a report covering fully the various points mentioned in the correspondence.

Private Secretary.

Sept. 25, 1932.

Memorandum

Mr. Baskard,

With reference to your memorandum of the 30th ultimo with regard to the claim of the Clayton Co., Ltd., in connection with their contract for the erection of the Indian School at Birtle, I beg to say that when tenders were being invited for this building the general site of the school had been agreed upon, and it was to be erected on the property immediately North of the existing school buildings, and the contractor was advised in the specifications that for further information he should apply to the Reverend Principal. The specifications also provided that before the firm submitted a tender they should visit the site of the proposed work and ascertain for themselves the nature of the soil to be excavated, the amount of excavation required and fully inform themselves as to all existing conditions. The specifications also further stated that when the contract was entered into that it was on the distinct understanding that he had investigated and satisfied himself as to all existing conditions.

I may say that the exact location of the school was not determined until the building was laid out on the property, but a difference of a hundred feet or so on the site would have made no difference in the nature of the soil to be excavated. When the barn was erected approximately 250 or 300 feet from the school the nature of the excavation was the same as for the main school building, and there appears to be no just reason why the Clayton Co. should be paid an extra for this work.

With reference to the fireplace the plans distinctly show that an open fireplace was required in the Principal's residence and there is no reason to suppose that same would be an electrical or more or less sham fireplace. The basement plans show the ash pit required for the fireplace, and the necessary chimney with flue is also indicated on the plans. This extra asked by the Clayton Co. was therefore not allowed.

Crane Limited, 95 Lombard Street, Winnipeg, have a debit of $1.24 on their books against the Department of Indian Affairs. This debit can be accounted for as follows.

On December 16, 1930 certain materials were ordered by the undersigned from Crane Limited to be shipped, freight prepaid, to David Henderson, Birtle Indian School, in connection with the water supply installation. No purchases were made from Crane Limited during 1931 nor since, yet on October 29, 1931 or eight months after your account was balanced and closed out, they evidently discovered this unpaid freight bill of $1.24 due on the shipment of December 16, 1930, and forwarded the invoices under date of December 30, 1930, which invoice I now enclose. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No; 106-1-5 of the 26th instant, with reference to the request received for the old classroom building at the Birtle Residential School.

2. On this date at 5:00 A.M. I left this detachment and patrolled by C.P.H.Y. to Birtle, where at 9:00 A.M. I interviewed Mr. H.B. Currie with reference to this complaint, and he informed me as follows:-- The old Indian School was abandoned about 18 months ago, and some of the furniture was moved to the new school, and some was left in the old building. On each floor every door was locked and all windows fastened. As the new school is nearly a quarter of a mile from the old one, Mr. Currie very seldom had occasion to visit it, but almost every week the janitor of the new school went to the old building to get some small article which might be needed in the way of repairs for the heating plant etc. On many of these trips he would report to Mr. Currie that several windows were broken out of the vacant building, and then about 6 months ago he commenced reporting that some of the old articles were missing. Mr. Currie made inspections on several occasions and said that the building had been entered apparently through the broken window on the ground floor as the locks on the doors were always intact. He did not report this to the Police as had no information to give them as to who the guilty parties might be so the contents of the building continued to disappear.

Last week, about January 24th, Mr. Currie had his man Mr. Ingram (janitor) make an estimate of the missing articles, and the following are the articles gone from the three dormitories:- 4 large mattresses, for double bed, badly worn; about 20 small mattresses, child's for single bed, all used and badly worn; about 22 patchwork quilts, all badly worn; 2 yard lengths and colours, some of these quilts were wrapped around large bundles of wool, and the wool was left in the building.

On January 30th, Mr. Currie again sent his man to the vacant school, and he came back and reported that the door on a building used as a store room was broken in, and the footprints of a man were seen around the door in the snow. Mr. Currie went to investigate, and on examining the interior of the building, missed a small square nickel clock about 7 x 4 x 6 inches, which played a tune when running, he stated that other articles might

Accompanied by Mr. Robert Ingram, I made a thorough examination of the vacant school, and the outbuildings, and to me it appeared as if things in the main building were very much out of order, nearly every window glass in the building was broken, some it appeared had been broken by stones at a distance, and others looked as if they had been broken at close range with something object. Several mattresses in the building had apparently been opened and the filling taken out, left on the floor, and the covering taken away, beds had been taken apart and were strewn about the floors, and a large quantity of wool was also thrown about the floor; this old piano stand was stripped up in some of the missing quilts, small kind organ was in the dining room, and this had the back boards taken in and some of the keys damaged. An examination of the storeroom referred to in this report showed that the panel door had been split in two by some heavy object, perhaps an axe, and things were also strewn about inside. A set of footprints were visible at the door outside, these were the footprints of a man, wearing about a size 7 shoe covered by a new rubber, other footprints were about the buildings but were very indistinct, and it would be impossible to ascertain whether they had been made by the culprit or by Mr. Ingram on some of his visits. Clear of the two footprints made by the new rubber, I could find no other clue which was of any value, so returned to Mr. Currie's office.

4. I again interviewed Mr. Currie, and he stated that he thought that some of the quilts had been taken by some of the Indians from the Waywayseecappo Reserve at Rossburn, as many of them were in the habit of coming to Birtle weekly to see their children at the School, and he, Mr. Currie, had fitted out a room in the old school with old mattresses and quilts for their benefit on these visits, this room was locked however and only opened when necessary. Regarding the other missing articles Mr. Currie stated he had no idea as to who had taken it, but was sure that the Indians did not do so.

5. I might mention at this point that the vacant school is sort of shut off from view from the new school, and could be looted in daytime without much danger of discovery, as there are no houses within sight of it, and it is about a mile from the main part of the town of Birtle, and the damage done to the windows according to Mr. Currie was in the vicinity of $100.00 as about 50 large panes of glass were broken, this of course could have been done by some of the Indian pupils at the new school, as they have a playground not far from the vacant building, and easily within stone throwing distance. The bedding which is missing Mr. Currie stated he could not put a price on, but was not of great value and was left there with a view of selling it.

6. I asked Mr. Currie if he suspected anyone in the town of Birtle for taking these articles, and he said he had no reason to do so, but it appeared to him that it had not gone far out of the town.

7. The janitor Mr. Ingram it appears to me is out of the question of suspicion, as he is a single man, and lives in quarters in the new school and appears to be a very reliable sort of a fellow.

8. Failing to get any further information from either Mr. Currie or Mr. Ingram I proceeded to the office of the Indian Agent Mr. P. Lazenby in the town of Birtle, and interviewed him, but he unfortunately was unable to give me any
information, but stated that he did not think that the Indians were responsible for taking this bedding, as they were in need of bedding all they had to do was come and see him, Mr. Isenby, and he would see that they were looked after.

9. I interviewed Sam Tompkins, Town Constable of Birtle, and he was unable to give me much information, but stated that a half breed family named Vive who lived on the road allowance a short distance from town might have taken some of it, as they were in very poor circumstances, and no doubt would need bedding.

10. Thinking that it might be well to see this Pat Vive, I engaged livery team and patrolled to his home, just a few miles from Birtle, but was not in possession of a Search Warrant to search his place and held him so, but he stated he could search it if he liked, there was no necessity however as he lives in a one-room shack and at a glance one could see that he could have no bedding concealed in it; neither had he any outbuildings. This man and his family are in very poor circumstances, and have very little bedding except old coats etc.

11. I returned to Birtle and spent the entire day in making enquiries regarding the disappearance of the bedding, but could gather no information of any value.

12. It appears to me as if the windows in the school have been broken by the pupils, and the fact that the windows were cut sort of invited some person or persons to enter the school and take the bedding, and one would imagine that it was taken by a number of persons, as a large amount of bedding such was taken would not be of any value to one party unless they intended to sell it.

13. Failing to get any further information, I returned to this detachment by C.P.R., at 1-20 A.M., February 2nd, 1933.

14. In view of the lack of information in this case I respectfully suggest that this file be considered closed.

15. Expense statement submitted.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of February 6th with reference to Mr H.S. Stead's account for $113.15 submitted to you in December 1931, covering repair work at the Birtle Indian School.

I think that the correspondence referred to in the first paragraph of your letter will show that Mr Stead was instructed to proceed to Birtle and repair the leaky joints etc., and was given to understand that he was to submit an account to you covering such work. Inasmuch as the arrangement made with Mr Stead, when called upon to carry out the installation of the water supply system to the Birtle Indian School, was that he was to receive ten percent profit on the proven cost of the work, I do not see any justification for the Department of Indian Affairs withholding payment of Mr Stead's account, provided you are satisfied that the amount charged is reasonable and just.

Referring to Mr Stead's letter to you under date of January 14th, I wish to take exception to his statement that the leaks that occurred were due to improper action of the pump. I may say that identical installations were made at the Indian Schools at Brandon, Kenora, and McIntosh and no trouble was experienced whatsoever in connection with the pipe connections, and in no case was it necessary to add the so-called air chambers to the pump. Furthermore, at the time final settlement was being made with Mr Stead covering the cost of the original work, it was explained to him by the writer that no investigation whatever would be given by the undersigned to the matter of interest charges levied against him by the bank. It was pointed out that such charges were the liability of the contractor in every instance.

Yours truly,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No; 106-105 of the 1st February, having further reference to the account of Mr H.S. Stead of Neepawa, for extra work done in connection with the water system at the Birtle Indian Residential School.

As suggested in your letter, I wrote very fully to Mr Gow at Winnipeg, in the matter, and asked him for his recommendation, and enclose herewith a copy of his reply. For his information, I forwarded to Mr Gow, a copy of Mr Stead's last letter to me, written under date of the 14th January. A copy of this letter of Mr Stead's was also forwarded to the Department on the 20th January.

It will be seen from Mr Gow's letter, that he is of the opinion that there is no justification for the Department withholding payment of Mr Stead's account, as the original agreement was that he be paid on a cost plus 10% basis for his work. In this, however, I am at variance with Mr Gow. It may possibly be that technically, the Department may be liable for payment of the account, seeing that Mr Stead was not under a specific form of contract. It stands to reason, however, that if he had done the work properly in the first instance, the second account, for making good the defective work, would have been totally unnecessary.

It will be also seen from Mr Gow's letter, that he takes exception to Mr Stead's statement that the leaks he was called upon to repair, were caused by the fact that the pump did not have large enough air chambers on it. These leaks, in my opinion, were due to inefficient pipe-fitting in the first place, and this inefficiency was, to my mind conclusively.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.;
conclusively proven later on, when we were called upon to repair a break in the pipe line, and it was found that the pipes were only holding in the connections by two threads.

The Claydon Company, who of course were under a definite contract, had to send their men from Winnipeg to Birtle several times, to make good defects in the work for which they were responsible; and at no extra cost to the Department. Is Mr Stead, under an agreement to do certain work on a cost plus 10% basis, justified in charging the Department for extra work done in making good defects that would not have occurred if his work in the first instance had been properly done? My opinion is that he is not, and I therefore cannot feel justified in recommending that such account be paid.

Your obedient Servant,
