The old Birtle Indian Residential School is hereby offered for sale, and the following particulars cover the demolishing and removal of same.

Tenders shall be enclosed in a sealed envelope addressed to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and clearly marked on the envelope—“Tender for old Birtle Indian Residential School, Birtle, Man.” An accepted cheque on a chartered bank of Canada, made payable to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, to the amount of the tender shall be enclosed with the tender.

Before submitting a tender the bidders shall visit the building, examine for themselves its present condition, and ascertain for themselves the nature of the work, and fully inform themselves as to all existing condition, especially as to risks, accidents, damage, etc., which might result from the above mentioned work.

The firms submitting a tender shall be required to provide and send in with tender a marked cheque for FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS ($500.00) accepted by a chartered bank of Canada, and made payable to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs. This cheque will be held as deposit security until the satisfactory completion of the contract.

Unsuccessful tenderers shall have their cheques returned as soon as an offer has been accepted.

The contractor shall commence work immediately upon being notified of the acceptance of his offer, and shall proceed without delay, and when submitting a tender firms shall state the time required to complete the work.
The contractor shall be responsible for any injury to workers, pupils, staff of school and the general public, and shall take what precautions are necessary to safeguard against injury to persons or property. He shall be responsible for any and all damage done to adjoining buildings. Where any walls are in a dangerous condition they shall be shored before the roof is taken off to prevent same from falling, and props shall be placed under the ceiling joints where there is danger of the brickwork falling. The outside walls of the entire building shall be demolished in such a way as to maintain a uniform height. All walls shall be taken down to at least 18" below grade level, and old basement must not be filled higher than will allow for 18" of earth over top of same. The contractor will not be expected to provide this earth filling, but will leave the old foundation graded level ready to receive the top dressing.

Chimneys and air shafts also hot air flues shall be taken down as the demolishing of the walls proceeds on a corresponding level, and not allowed to stand with the idea of pulling them over afterwards.

The Contractor shall have all electric light wires disconnected before proceeding with the work, and all loose wires hanging outside that might be dangerous shall be removed.

Before removing the plumbing fixtures the contractor shall have the water disconnected from the building and then the fixtures are removed carefully and up the ends of water pipes.

Materials must not be allowed to accumulate on floors. No lumber or shingles shall be used to fill in old basement.

All materials in the building, together with
all attached fixtures and fittings shall become the property of the Contractor, and shall be removed from the premises.

All stone and brick in the existing building may be used to fill in the basement, providing the filling does not reach higher than 10" above finished grade, as above specified. All material over and above this must be removed from the premises.

If the Contractor so desires he may remove all the stone and brick in the building from the premises.

Dear Sir,

re Indian School, Birtle. Your file 106-1-15.

When our final account on contract for the above school was being paid, a deduction of $1,114.77 was made from it. $225.00 of this is in order, but the balance of $989.77., should, we believe, have been paid to us.

The above amount is made up of items No. 10 and 23, of our account of February 28th, 1931., copies of each being attached hereto.

It is possible a further explanation of our position may result in your deciding to pay the amount to us.

It has been previously stated why we made the charges. Item No. 10, $102.21, is for facings etc. only, for fireplace and hearth in superintendent's residence. They were not indicated on plan or mentioned in the specifications. We made no charge for the rough brickwork or flue, as these were implied by drawings, though not specified. A verbal order for the items charged was given to us by Mr. Henderson, the Inspector, who later wrote us under date of October 20th, 1930., telling us what to supply, and after giving our foreman his verbal order, wrote us on November 5th, asking for a price, but we had by that time ordered the material. We purchased, and paid for the material by special order.

Regarding item No. 23, $787.56. This is an expense that could not possibly have been foreseen unless the exact location of the school was indicated to us before the contract was let. We did examine the site, and had the school been placed on 50 to 60 feet further North, no difficulty in excavating would have been encountered. As it was, we found boulders in hardpan, which next to rock, is the most difficult material to dig. All we charged...
additional was the bare freight on our machine, the cost of loading and unloading (which cost at least $150.00) being borne by ourselves.

The general details regarding this item are covered in our letter to Mr. Scott, dated March 20th, 1931. We also wrote to the Hon. T. C. Murphy who replied under date of April 13th, 1931. His concluding paragraph was, "However I will be glad to consider the matter a little later on".

If we are allowed the same latitude as is given on railway construction, a classification would be given. The railway classifications for dry excavation are as follows. 1, earth. 2, clay. 3, hardpan and boulders. 4, rock.

The extra work was confined to the main portion of the building, the rear annex, chapel etc., being clay formation only. The yardage in basement of main building is about 1260 yds., and for this small amount an additional allowance of say 70¢ per yard is an extremely low differential.

We request that you take special note of the fact that after our tender for the building was mailed, we received a lower price on a few items, notably brick and tile. We immediately wired Mr. Scott a credit of $2094.00. This was deducted from our tender although, without counting the credit, it was the lowest received. What we are asking is a very moderate charge for the work done, and less than half the credit given as outlined above.

We were denied what is almost a general contractors right, to put in the water supply and sewage disposal systems, something the like of which we have never experienced, and while we can make every allowance for the circumstances which governed such procedure, it appears to us as an added reason why the adjustment we seek should be allowed us.

We believe it might be preferable to pay us by classification, and if you agree with this we suggest payment be made in accordance with statement enclosed herewith.

Every custom of the construction industry supports our claim, and we trust it may receive your favourable consideration.

Yours faithfully,

AT
BIRTLE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.
INTRODUCTORY:

In response to the request of the Department of Indian Affairs, as contained in your letter of November 15th, Mr. J. T. Rose of this office and the writer visited the Birtle Indian School and made inquiries as to the trouble being experienced with the high pressure boiler, domestic water heater and heating system. An examination was made of the pumping installation, the chlorinator and the water filter. A sample of the water as used in the school after chlorination and filtration was taken and has been analyzed by the Milton-Hersey Company Limited. This analysis has been our basis for determining the probable causes of the trouble experienced and also for determining the most effective and cheapest method of eliminating the trouble experienced.

TROUBLES EXPERIENCED:

Our inspection showed the pumps, chlorinator, filter and cold water system functioning very satisfactorily. The heating system is giving no trouble, only one unit being in operation, although the day of our visit was quite cold. The heating system has been and is functioning satisfactorily, ever since the boiler room was properly drained two years ago.

However, it was laundry day at the school and the inconvenience resulting from the failure of the high pressure steam boiler and the hot water supply boiler was only too evident. It was explained to us that the tubing in the high pressure steam boiler had corroded very badly.
particularly above the water line in the boiler and that the tubing had to be replaced. Pieces of the removed tubing shown us were badly corroded. The hot water supply heater became useless because of the cracking of the lining and upper sections. One of these sections shown us appeared to be badly burned away, rather than corroded.

CAUSES OF TROUBLE:

To determine the cause of the trouble in these two units of the hot water supply system, it is necessary to study the chemical analysis of the water. This analysis shows 35.15 grains of hardness per imperial gallon - this hardness being composed of Calcium Carbonate, Calcium Sulphate and Magnesium Carbonate. The presence of these incrusting solids causes this water to be classed as hard water and are undoubtedly the cause of the trouble experienced with the hot water supply boiler. These two carbonates in solution in the water are deposited when subjected to heat under pressure, forming scale which may or may not be hard on the sides of the boiler. The scale thus formed is usually a good non-conductor of heat and accordingly diminishes the efficiency of the heater. With the decrease of efficiency, forcing of the heat applied becomes common practice and the unit is soon burned out. The incrustation of solids such as Calcium Sulphate, which is present in this water, is extremely hard and becomes firmly attached to the lining and prevents the cooling action of the water from protecting the metal against burning. Furthermore, the hot water supply boiler installed at Birtle was not designed to
operate under pressure exceeding twenty to twenty-five pounds - at least so I am informed by the contractor who installed the unit.

In view of the analysis shown of the water in use it is difficult to decide what has caused the rapid corrosion experienced with the high pressure steam boiler. The analysis does not reveal the presence of any solids which by themselves are corrosive. Since even the purest of waters are corrosive, it is but natural that corrosion occurs throughout the water supply system at Birtle. The probable cause of the rapid rate of corrosion in this high pressure steam boiler has been taken up with several people connected with steam boilers in Winnipeg and various explanations were given. It is possible that the ordinary corrosive action of the water becomes intensified in the high pressure steam boiler and again it may be that the non-corrosive incrusting solids in this water, under high pressure heating, react with the non-incrusting solids to form acids or other corrosive agencies.

**ELIMINATION OF TROUBLE:**

I understand a new hot water supply boiler is being installed at the school and that it is designed to operate under the pressure prevailing there. Such being the case, softening of the water supply sufficiently to remove the incrusting solids, should prevent a repetition of the trouble experienced up to date with the hot water supply boiler.

However, the writer is not prepared to say that such a process will eliminate the trouble experienced with the high pressure steam boiler. If the rapid corrosion is
entirely due to the reaction between the incrusting solids and other elements in the water under the process of being heated and converted into steam, then the removal of these incrusting solids should materially, if not entirely, eliminate corrosion. If these solids have little or no action in causing the rapid corrosion, then their removal would not materially lessen the corrosive action experienced.

I would suggest that a water softening plant be installed in the school of sufficient capacity to provide a softened water supply for the following services in the Institution:

(1) Steam heating system.
(2) High pressure steam boiler system.
(3) Hot Water Supply boiler system.
(4) Limited supply of cold water to laundry and kitchen.

The advantages to the Department of Indian Affairs would be elimination of repairs to and a prolongation of the usefulness of the heating system and the hot water supply system and a probability of greatly decreased repair bills in connection with the high pressure steam boiler. The advantages to the operators of the school are obvious and the savings effected in clothing, use of soap etc., greatly offsets the cost of the operation of the water softener.

PROPOSED INSTALLATION:

The quantity of water supplied daily to the water supply system of the Birtle School varies considerably. 7,700 gallons - the average daily supply for February, 1933 - being the maximum and 2,500 gallons - the average daily supply for July, 1933 - being the minimum recorded during the period September, 1932 to date. The average daily use for the year ending September 31st, 1933 was 5,700 gallons.
It is impossible to estimate offhand the average daily use of water in this school for purposes which it is most desirable that softened water be supplied. On general wash-day and laundry-day, the quantity of water used would be large. The new hot water supply boiler is only capable of heating 250 gallons of water 100° Fah. in one hour. The school heating system uses a very small amount of water and the high pressure steam boiler is only operated occasionally and utilizes little water as compared with the hot water boiler. Accordingly, it is proposed to install a water softener that will provide 500 gallons of water with zero hardness per hour with 2,500 to 3,000 gallons capacity between regenerations. While it is expected that the school authorities will limit the average daily use of softened water to less than 1,000 gallons in any month, yet it is advisable to install a unit that will provide for a maximum washday use of 2,500 gallons without requiring regeneration. The cost of operation will probably discourage the school authorities from extravagant use of softened water.

It is proposed that the water softener be installed in the boiler room at the Birtle Indian School and along the north wall adjacent to the stairway. Installation is simple as the feed pipe to the hot water supply boiler and high pressure steam boiler can be cut at this position. Some extra one inch piping will be necessary to supply soft water to the laundry and kitchen. The drain from the boiler room is immediately available and will adequately care for the water wasted during the regeneration process.
Manufacturers' Agents in Winnipeg have been requested to submit proposals with quotations for a water softener delivered F.O.B. Birtle, to provide 500 gallons of water at zero hardness with capacity for 2,500 to 3,000 gallons between regenerations and based upon a total hardness of 35 grains per imperial gallon in the water to be softened. It is anticipated that all proposals will provide for a double unit utilizing the zeolite method of softening and also Delcaso Mineral or Synthetic Mineral.

ESTIMATES OF COST:

The cost of a water softener at the Birtle Indian School depends almost entirely upon the capacity of the unit between regenerations, since all manufacturers using the zeolite process are subject to the same patent restrictions. The cost of installation would be practically the same regardless of the capacity within the limits outlined of course.

PROPOSAL NO. 1.

Single Unit. Capacity between regenerations on 36 grain water, 1,300 gallons - - - - - - - $300.00

Cost of Installation - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - 25.00

Total Cost- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - $325.00

PROPOSAL NO. 2.

Double Unit. Capacity between regenerations on 36 grain water, 2,500 gallons - - - - - - - $580.00

Cost of Installation - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - 45.00

Total Cost- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - $625.00

These two estimates of cost cover about the cheapest installation that can be considered. Proposal No. 1 requires approximately twenty-four pounds of salt per regeneration, while Proposal No. 2 would require
forty-seven pounds of salt per regeneration - the cost of salt for each regeneration in each case being approximately .35¢ and .70¢ respectively.

SUGGESTIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS:

I would recommend the installation of a double unit water softener in the Birtle Indian School with a total capacity on 36 grain water of not less than 2,500 imperial gallons between regenerations. If such a softener is installed, I would suggest that the water supply feed line piping be slightly rearranged so as to provide soft unheated water to the laundry and kitchen.

I believe the water softener will eliminate the trouble experienced with the hot water supply boiler and will possibly decrease the rapid rate of erosion in the high pressure steam boiler.

Should the water softener be installed the operators of the school must expect some trouble for some months from scale being released from the piping etc., possibly causing blocking of feed lines and also causing annoyance with the water supply.

Dear Sir,

I beg to advise you that I was called to the Residential School yesterday, to see the auxiliary water heating coil, that is situated above the left hand boiler, and which is connected with the jacket heating system.

The engineer took the cover off this coil to see why it was not operating properly, and the inside is so filled up with scale that it was impossible to even see any coils there at all, and the scale is just about as hard as cement. Naturally the water could not circulate around the steam coils.

Furthermore, about a week ago, the engineer disconnected a pipe from one of the registers, or rather, radiators; and the inside of the pipe was so full of corrosion that a lead pencil could not be inserted in it.

It would appear that unless something is done very shortly to remedy the situation, the whole system will get into such a condition that it will cost a great deal of money to put it right.

When Mr. Gow was here some time ago, he took a sample of the water back to Winnipeg with him for analysis, to find out if possible, what might be the cause of all this corrosion, but as yet I have had no word from him, in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

The Water Softener to be installed in the Indian Residential School at Birtle, Manitoba, has arrived in Winnipeg and is being transshipped to Birtle. Arrangements have been made for the installation of the Water Softener in the school and it is expected that the installation will be complete within the next two or three weeks.

As I understand the situation, the primary reason for the installation of the water softener was to secure softened water for use in the heating plant of the school, in the water supply system and also in the high pressure steam boiler, in order to eliminate the rapid rate of erosion that is taking place throughout these installations. It is true that a limited amount of softened water will be made available for the use of the operators of the school. It is estimated that each regeneration of the water softener will utilize approximately forty-seven pounds of salt, with a water hardness of 57 grains per imperial gallon; the cost of the salt being about .70¢ for each regeneration.

Before putting this unit into operation, it is necessary to have a supply of salt available. The question arises who is responsible for the cost of the salt? I might point out that this question has not been discussed with the Principal of the School or with any of the officials connected with that institution and no salt has been ordered until such time as the Department of Indian Affairs can advise us as to who is to be responsible for supplying salt for use in the water softener.

It is desired to order one ton of salt for delivery at the earliest possible date and it would be appreciated if this matter could be taken up with the Department of Indian Affairs and a reply forwarded at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to report that at about 10 a.m. on the morning of the 16th April, the poultry house recently erected at the Birtle Residential School from materials salvaged from the old school building, was destroyed by fire, through the exploding of a coal heated chicken brooder.

This building was just recently completed, and the Principal had purchased a large brooder, second hand, and had ordered 1,000 chicks. The brooder was placed in the building and was being tried out by one of the men of the staff, using small soft coal for the fire. The fire had been going for two days, and on the morning of the 16th the fire was made up, and left as usual, when shortly afterwards the building was seen to be in flames. It is supposed that gas had accumulated in the stove of the brooder, and had exploded, scattering the red hot coals about, which started the fire.

The building was 18 feet wide, and 66 feet long, well built, with floors, partitions, double walls with building paper between, trap nests &c; and the labour cost was $177.25, for the erection; the materials used, as stated above, were taken from the old school building.

In considering the replacing of this building, on which no insurance was carried, the school still has a quantity of good material that can be used. However, they lack drop siding for the walls, shingles for the roof, windows, cement for the foundation, a quantity of

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.,
common boards for sheathing, and a quantity of dimension stuff for plates and studding.

The Principal had his carpenter estimate the materials required in addition to what they have on hand, and then had the local lumber dealer estimate the cost, which amounts to approximately $400.00.

They have purchased two new brooders as the 1,000 chicks arrived the morning after the fire, and have fixed up two temporary sheds for them in the meantime.

Will you please advise me if the Department will provide the material required, at a cost of $400.00, for the erection of a new poultry house.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sirs,

As you have already learned from Mr. Layenby, the Indian Agent, we suffered by fire, the loss of a hen house which we had just erected. The building was 26 feet long by 16 feet wide; built with 2 by 4 studs and rafters, double boarded with paper between, single glass windows along the entire front of 8 feet. Four partitions making five apartments well equipped with beds, cooking pots etc., tidy beds in two apartments. The material was taken from the old school. $500.00 would not replace what we lost. The cost for labor was $77.25.

As we have still on hand some of the material that will do for the erection of another building, I am therefore willing to undertake the building of another house if your Department will provide one half the cost, or the matter of $500.00.

A building 8 x 4 by 16 ft. will accommodate 350 hens. We have about 500 young chickens and therefore hope to have at least 350 hens to house next winter.

I took upon myself to insure some material—maple flooring etc.—which I have stored in a part of what was the classroom building for the old school. But learning that the Department cannot dispose of the buildings,
Birtle Manitoba,
9th July 1934.

Sir,

I beg to say that on receipt of your letter No. 106-1-5 of the 1st May last, in connection with the loss by fire of the newly erected poultry house at the Birtle Residential School, I consulted with the Principal in the matter, as to what other provision, if any might be made for the housing of the poultry.

We have discussed this matter several times since that date, without arriving at anything very definite.

I finally requested the Principal to put in the form of a letter, his views regarding the whole situation, and he has handed me the attached letter addressed to the Department.

In addition to this, I also asked the Principal to let me have a list of the materials that would have to be bought, to add to that that still remains on hand from the demolition of the old school building, to erect another building of sufficient size to accommodate his flock of poultry, and I am also attaching hereto the list he has provided, with the estimate of the cost.

As stated in previous correspondence, the Principal purchased 1,000 live chicks just before the poultry house was burned, and these were temporarily accommodated in two small out houses on their arrival. The number of chicks now left is approximately 800, and their size now precludes them being cared for in these small places, and it is necessary that proper housing be provided.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.;
provided for this large flock, unless the greater portion of them are to be sacrificed.

The Principal, since he took over the management of the school last September has done some splendid work in the providing of outbuildings, such as a large implement shed, hog pen, &c; as well as the poultry house which was destroyed by fire, and I would recommend that the Department give as favourable consideration as it possibly can to the Principal's request for assistance to build another poultry house.

Your obedient Servant

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I beg to report that a water main between the school building and the barn at the Residential School has burst creating a flooding of the surrounding land and ultimately finding its way to the boiler room in the basement of the school.

This water supply is piped from the Canadian Pacific Railway water tank at the station some 400 yards distant, the break appears to be at the North of the school building and to me it seems likely to be at the junction where distribution to school and barn is made, by closing off barn supply one gets the minimum of leakage whereas if barn supply is open hundreds of gallons of water will be wasted daily. Water is charged to this school by the gallonage from C.P.R.

I have ordered an excavation to be made at the point of flooding and trust the damage will not be too serious, however, I cannot fully state damage until the pipe line is uncovered, as pipe line is down fourteen feet and excavation difficult at this time of the year, it will be about 28th before an estimate of damage can be made.

Providing the trouble is centered at a poor joint or faulty coupling where the condition can be looked after locally, will you authorize me to go ahead at the least possible expense, or, would you rather I called in the firm who contracted for the installation of the system.

Your obedient Servant,

The Secretary,
Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir-

With reference to the water main condition at the Birtle Residential School as reported in my letter of Dec 26th 1934.

we found on excavation that corrosion of pipes was the cause of leakages. To overcome the heavy leakages an excavation sixty feet long and fifteen feet deep had to be made and about forty feet of pipe installed.

There is a possibility that the whole line of piping will have to be renewed, for there is still a slight leakage east of the excavation, however, it is too expensive to excavate under present weather conditions, so I halted the work until conditions are more favourable. The heavy leakage is now checked and wastage at present time will not exceed twenty gallons per day.

I have thoroughly examined the corroded piping, it is 2" black iron, the corrosion is external not internal, all corrosion is confined to the lower portion of pipe as laid on ground. I am at a loss to understand this condition as piping has only been installed a matter of four years. I note for some reason the pipe is wrapped in tar paper, the object of same I do not understand, it is possible a chemical reaction from tar paper, clay and moist iron has been created, this, however, is supposition only, but there must be some cause for this piping to corrode in this manner within the period of four years. Replacements have been made of galvanized malleable iron piping.

Excavation is now being filled in and on completion vouchers will go forward for material and labour. Condition will be watched and a report sent about the month of June.

Sir:

Mr. Dunn the engineer of the Birtle Residential School asked me to inspect the water closet bowls in the toilets. I found three broke on the girls side and one on the boys. One is completely broke, and the other three at the bases which causes flooding.

It is requested that they be supplied with four new ones, and the estimated cost would be about $20. a piece, a total of $80. dollars.

Sir:

I beg to report that a water main between the school and barn at the Residential School appears to be leaking. The ground over the pipe line is saturated and starting to cave in, and water lying in the holes. This is immediately east of where the pipes had been fixed in January. MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

The Acting Indian Agent, Birtle, Man., reports that the water main between the school and barn at the Indian Residential School, Birtle (Electoral District of Marquette), Man., is leaking. The Agent states the ground over the pipeline is saturated and starting to cave in. He recommends that the pipeline be excavated and new water pipe installed. There are certain funds available in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year, for repairs at this school.

Dear Sir:

On the occasion of the installation of Mr. A. G. Smith, Indian Agent, Birtle, I visited the Indian Residential School.

The Principal, the Rev. E. Lockhart, was greatly worried because ten pupils had run away. I made careful enquiries and am of the opinion that the children were homesick. They had only returned from holidays and it usually takes a few weeks before they settle down. The children are well treated and receive plenty of well prepared food. They are also well clothed and the boys are certainly not overworked.

The school building was in excellent condition. A painter was busy decorating the Principal's suite. He has been working inside the school for nearly two months. Almost the entire building has been painted inside. The paint used comprises light shades, consequently the building is quite bright and cheerful. This work has all been paid for without extra assistance from the Department. I consider Mr. Lockhart deserves great credit for the splendid condition of the school residence.

The women in charge of the various departments appear capable and interested in their work.

The children were in good health and appeared happy. A graduate nurse is kept and I understand from the doctor that she is very observant and watches carefully.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
over the health of the pupils.

The machinery all appeared to be in good condition and I found the furnace room tidy. The chlorinator, filter, and water softener were all in good working order.

Since the repair of the water line from the school to the barn, the consumption has been reduced by about half. The pipe was almost completely destroyed, allowing a great waste of water.

The barns and other outbuildings are in good repair. These buildings all need painting. I understand the construction of the buildings was completed late in the fall and, although the lumber was not dry, they were immediately painted. The result is that the paint has all peeled off, leaving the buildings in bad condition. The Rev. Principal is willing to do the work if the Department will supply the paint, oil, etc. In view of the painting already done by the Principal, I feel the Department should, if possible, supply the paint in connection with the outbuildings. The amount required to make a complete job will be approximately $300.00. The work perhaps could not be completed this year, but could be carried on and completed early next spring.

The farm consists of 840 acres and this year the land cropped amounted to 300 acres. Threshing was not completed at the time of my visit, but the returns will be small, due largely to rust conditions.

The stock was all in excellent condition and is as follows:

- 42 head purebred Shorthorn cattle
- 16 horses
- 25 sheep
- 40 pigs
- 100 chickens

The farm
The farm land is mostly new breaking and, if Mr. Lockhart is fortunate in obtaining a couple of good years, he should be able to find it quite easy to finance. He is familiar with farming and a hard, persistent worker. He is fond of the children and, if anything, too lenient. Unfortunately, he is not popular with the Indians, due largely to the fact that he has restricted their visiting days and will not allow them to camp on the school property for indefinite periods.

Mrs. Lockhart is Matron and I consider her an efficient member of the staff. She is fairly strong on discipline, but certainly not unreasonable.

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, November 6, 1935.

Sir:

I have your 201-11 of the 2nd instant, reporting on your visit of inspection of the Birtle Indian Residential School.

It is noted that general conditions at this school are satisfactory, that the school building was in excellent condition and that the Principal, without expense to the Department, has carried out considerable redecorating in his living quarters. It is noted, further, that all machinery was in good condition and working satisfactorily.

Regarding the painting of the buildings, I have to say that, when our Estimates for the next fiscal year are being prepared, consideration will be given to including an amount of approximately $300 to purchase the paint and other materials required. It is noted the Principal is willing to do the work if the Department supplies the material.

With reference to the complaint of the Indians, that the Principal has restricted their visiting days, I would say, for your information, that the Department has had correspondence with the Principal in this regard. It appears that the Indians were imposing on the school staff by their frequent visits and the length of their stay. The Principal was instructed that, while giving the parents opportunity to see their children, he should not permit them to unnecessarily impose on the routine of the school and he was to set down definite visiting hours, when the parents could see their children.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

In accordance with the instructions contained in your letter of February 4th, we have had a chemical analysis made of the sample of water from the Hird's Indian Residential School and are enclosing herewith a copy of the same.

You will note from this Chemical Analysis that the water contains 77.13 grains of hardness per imperial gallon. In addition to the above the water also contains 84.55 grains per imperial gallon of non-incrusting solids, or a total of 161.68 grains per imperial gallon of solid matter. We are particularly interested, however, in the 77.13 grains of incrusting solids as these are the ones that must be removed by water softening.

The 77.13 grains of hardness corresponds with 35.15 grains as shown by the previous chemical analysis, taken under date of November 28, 1933. Accordingly at the present time it will take about twice the amount of salt to render this water soft. The amount of non-incrusting solids in 1933 was only 25.14 grains as compared with 84.55 found at the present time accordingly. This amounts for the deposit which is reported by the Principal of the School. There is nothing that can be done at present to render this water less difficult to soften. It will be necessary for the school authorities to re-generate twice as often as formerly and to use twice the amount of salt.

This condition of the water is undoubtedly due to the very low flow being experienced in the Birdtail Creek at the present time and to the lack of pondage facilities as a result of the washing away of the dam last spring. It is anticipated that with the spring break-up, this excessive hardness of the water will disappear and the present trouble will be eliminated.

We are today writing to the Principal of the School, giving him the results of the chemical analysis and pointing out that there is nothing in particular that can be done at the present time to eliminate his difficulties but that we anticipate that with the opening up of the spring run-off, these difficulties will have disappeared.

Your obedient servant,

The Town Council of Birtle, in my constituency, requested a meeting to discuss the question of supplies to the Indian School at Birtle. I saw them last week and they informed me that practically no supplies are purchased in the Town for the Indian School. As you know, there are quite a large number of pupils in the school and they must do a lot of business, which would be a distinct advantage to the town. I received a petition signed by all the Merchants in the town, undertaking to give supplies to the school at 10% above cost price. If necessary, I will send you the Petition.

I presume that your Department has their own policy with regard to the purchase of supplies but the offer made by the Merchants seems to me to be reasonable.

I may point out that the school property is free from taxation and the residents of the school have the use of the roads and all public conveniences at no cost to the school or the Department. They also mention the fact that the school had made large purchases of timber in the community, depleting a very small reserve of timber in that locality. I would be obliged if you would look into the matter and let me know if something can be done along the lines indicated.

I am also informed, and I know the property sufficiently well to say that there is no value in the small corner through which the proposed fence would go. Dear Mr. Hoey:

Your letter 106-1-5 of Oct. 29, 1937, to hand. And I must say that I appreciate very much the courtesy and kindly tone that is evidenced in all your correspondence, and well I remember that in one of your letters you stated that you would like to help in any way you could the Superintendents of the Indian schools. I will certainly appreciate all the help you can give for the responsibilities and cares of such institutions are very great.

I wish you would write the Canadian Pacific Railway Company as to provision made for ingress and egress to the farm occupied by Mr. Bryden. Please note a dotted line I have made on the sketch you sent me. That indicates an ingress and egress for the occupant of that particular farm with a regular railway crossing provided and out by that road I can bring any load within reason. I can, with our little chore team, bring out a hundred bushels of wheat in a load, moving at a smart step, and without stopping to rest. I can with auto drive at fifteen miles per hour over this road from the highway to Mr. Bryden's house without being at all reckless. This road is as good as the road
he would like to have across the school property. In using this road which he has been using for several weeks, and which I certainly think he should continue to use, he is not half the distance from the elevators and railroad station as is the next nearest farmer.

And this quarter section is of value for pasture, for I am making very good use of it for that purpose. And before I did my fencing on this quarter, Mr. Bryden was making a very considerable use of it. There was, before my coming here, about one half of the quarter enclosed which Mr. Bryden was using and for which he had no lease. How could he or I be pasturing stock on land with no pasture and of no value?

Now, suppose I bought a farm and after a few years of ownership I decided to put a fence around it and for several years before fencing a neighbor had been shortening his trips to town by driving across a corner of my farm as indicated on paper herewith attached, who would for one moment think I would build my fence other than to take in the entire acreage? I submit that my neighbor would be most selfish and unreasonable if he expected me to run my fence across corner so as to allow him to continue on that shortcut across the corner of my farm.

I have never had the slightest clash with any member of the Birtle Council. Members thereof have expressed appreciation for work I have provided for men who would otherwise have been on their hands for relief. I am
very much surprised that they would make such an approach to you as they evidently have done. I am willing to do anything within reason. Dear Sir,

Re Drains, Indian School, Birtle, Man.

We have only now been able to assemble the necessary information to form an intelligent report. Some of our Staff being absent.

On being called to Birtle to clear the main drains our Plumber found that there had accumulated a stoppage, not in the drain that goes through the Septic Tank, but on that drain which is connected to the Laundry Machinery, the Kitchen Sink, floor drains in Laundry and the Drinking Fountains. This drain also takes all the rain water from the Roof.

The stoppage was composed of Grease, some Lint and broken half rusted wires from the roof cages showed in two places.

The waste stoppage was between the Boys Recreation Room and the Dining Room, and in this case about 25 ft of the Drain was plugged solid with grease. At this point, the cold water from the Boys Drinking Fountain enters this drain, contributing to a large extent on hardening the grease. At this point, the drain is 6" cast iron and had to be taken up to be cleaned, and some new pipe put in. We also installed a cleanout here to help in case of future trouble.

The lesser stoppage was in the same Drain but in the Tile Pipe near the Septic Tank where an offset in the Drain occurs. The average depth of this Drain is approximately 7 feet and was dug up in three places and eleven lengths of tile pipe had to be replaced.

The accumulation of rubbish, helped out by the broken rusted wires from the roof cages were the cause of the plug here.

We might suggest that all roof cages protecting the outlets of rainwater pipes should be made of copper.

While this drain was plugged, a severe rain storm occurred, causing considerable inconvenience and some damage.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 12th instant, file 106-1-5, I wish to report that I visited the Birtle School on July 28th, in company with Agent Smith.

We went carefully through the whole building and the floors are certainly badly cracked and, in many cases, very unlevel. The fault, I am convinced, has nothing to do with the foundation of the building because there is scarcely a crack in any of the walls. In my opinion, the steel work on which the cement floor was laid, was of too weak a structure and the floor settled in the areas between the main supports. I am not in a position to recommend what action should be taken, but would suggest that this matter be given over to the Engineering Department for their advice. I think it would be useless to attempt to lay another floor without first putting down the steel work to carry it, and this, along with the weight of the cement, would perhaps be too heavy for the building. It might be possible to clean out the cracks and fill them in with something and then cover the halls and some of the main rooms with battleship linoleum. I am sure this latter suggestion would be the cheaper and probably the most satisfactory.

A lot of work is required to fix the front grounds, and it will be necessary to put down some walks and a certain amount of cement cribbing. The cement, lumber and gravel required will cost at least $125.00. In addition to this, it will be necessary to haul at least 250 yds. of good soil and 100 yds. of gravel and before any of the work is started, labour will be required for the levelling of the present yard. It will take at least

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.
$225.00 for labour. In estimating the amount required as $350.00, I want to make it clear that this will not in any way give a complete job, but will fix up the portion of the grounds in front of the school, after which, I think the principal should be able to add further improvements from year to year.

The horses and machinery required will be furnished by the school. I would recommend that Mr. Smith be given an accountable advance, as the men engaged in this work will expect their pay every Saturday.

Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Birtle Indian Residential School,
Birtle, Manitoba.

Referring to your memorandum of the 11th ultimo with regard to the above, a report has now been received from Mr. Atkinson who made an inspection recently of the above school.

From Mr. Atkinson's report it would seem that he made as careful an inspection as was possible under the circumstances, taking at the same time actual floor levels in order to ascertain whether there had been any structural changes in the building. Mr. Atkinson was not, however, able to procure copy of the specifications for materials etc., used in the original construction of this school. He did, however, examine files available, from which he observed that in February, 1931, one letter stated: "Several cracks in floors throughout the building will want filling up and levelling off". This would appear to indicate that there was early trouble in connection with floor cracks. Mr. Atkinson was further advised that the cracks in the floor are worse now than they were five years ago, from which it would seem that these cracks first appeared shortly after construction of the building in 1931 and have since widened somewhat.

From levels taken and a general examination of the walls etc., it does not appear, however, that the cracks in question are results of unequal settlement of the building.

In view of the evidence of the same type of checking in all floors throughout the structure including basement floors, it is Mr. Atkinson's opinion that these cracks are a result of the method used in laying and finishing the concrete surface. In any case it is evident from Mr. Atkinson's report that whatever may be the actual cause, there is no serious structural condition at this school and, therefore, that it is merely a matter of the method to be used in remedying the conditions which now exist. In this connection, however, Mr. Atkinson does make the further suggestion that if it is thought advisable to do anything further to assure that there are no structural defects, this might be done by taking the matter up with Mr. Govt. of Winnipeg and Mr. W. Swan, Architect, Punnichy, Saskatchewan, who it would appear were interested in the actual construction of the building in question.

As regards repairs, it would appear that with few exceptions the cracks are so very slight that a filling

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
of any kind would be practically useless and could not be generally applied to any advantage. It is, therefore, suggested that a mastic cement finish might be applied on the floors or the situation might be met by covering all main floors throughout the building with felt and battleship linoleum. In Mr. Atkinson's opinion this would appear to be necessary even though the floors were in good shape as according to his report the building is a very cold structure with no floor covering whatsoever in any part.

We have no cost estimate for any of the above suggestions for handling the trouble, but same could be secured if the Indian Affairs Branch desire such information.

Respectfully submitted,

T. O. Miller

Attached to this letter you will find copies of the boiler inspection reports on your heating and high pressure boilers.

I may say that the high pressure boiler will have to be retubed, as the tubes are about pitted through at the water line. If possible, it would be far more economical to replace this boiler with a horizontal type, in which the tubes would last for at least twenty years. Mr Greeves will do a complete job on this boiler for $135.00, including the new tubes and other material required, or will put in new tubes at a cost of $75.00 for labour. If the Department do not desire to replace this boiler with a horizontal one I would suggest that Mr Greeves tender on a complete job be accepted.

In the vertical boiler part of the flues are not submerged, and that is where they become pitted. In a horizontal boiler the whole flue is submerged, hence they last for years with proper care. The advantage in a vertical boiler is that hot water may be had in 30 minutes, whereas in a horizontal boiler it would take two hours. The engineer at the school informs me that a horizontal boiler would be satisfactory, as they could put in a fire at night; it would soon steam up in the morning. I think this boiler should be attended to as soon as possible, as it is not safe in its present condition.

Regarding the low pressure boilers at the school, Mr Fuller the Provincial boiler Inspector reports that the boilers are in good condition, but the tubes show signs of pitting on account of using softened water only. Mr Fuller recommends that a lime wash be fed to the boilers every two weeks or that hard water be used for a season. The engineer at the school
informed me that a lime wash can only be fed when the boilers are cooled down. During the winter months the boilers are never cooled, so it is impossible to use a lime wash regularly.

To connect the boilers to the hard water line a certain amount of piping, connections, and fittings are necessary, which can be purchased from Mr. Ross Brown of Birtle for $26.80. The engineer at the school can do the work himself without cost.

I am enclosing a list of material required for this connection, and as this small expenditure will save the tubing in the boilers according to information received, I recommend that the material be supplied.

Memorandum Re - Birtle Indian School Water Supply Line.

General Description.

A gravity water supply line was laid from Birtle C.P.R. station water tank to the Birtle Residential School in October, 1930. The line was of 2½ inch pipes and totalled nearly 1,400 feet in length and was placed in a trench at an average depth of about ten feet. As there was much cinder fill in the station yard under which the pipe had to be laid 500 feet of the pipe leading away from the tank was supplied in galvanized iron specially wrapped with treated paper. The remaining 1,100 feet was wrought iron wrapped pipe, laid through brush covered and open field.

It might be noted that a 1½ inch wrought iron pressure line laid for a distance of about 600 feet between the school and barns had to be replaced after six years' use. This pipe was badly pitted on the underside, particularly, with some deterioration along the top. No pitting appeared to affect the seam of the pipe or the inside, particularly.

Leakage Repairs.

This spring unusual flooding was noticed in the bush adjacent to the line at a distance of about 150 to 300 feet from the school. In May the metered water supply leaving the C.P.R. tank was noted to be much higher than for the previous year, being 53,610 cubic feet, as compared to 37,530 cubic feet for the previous year. Welling up of water occurred at a spot about 150 feet from the school and overflow into the bush went on when the C.P.R. tank was full and pressure had built up in the line by the gravity pressure of nearly 30 feet of water. It was thought the welling up might indicate a point where repairs could be effected, so in the middle of June digging was done and two definite leaks in one 20 foot length 135 to 135 feet from the school were located and temporarily repaired. However, flow of water coming out either the pipe at either end of the sections excavated indicated further leakage. Each section uncovered was badly pitted all along the bottom of the pipe. Holes were difficult to find as there was no pressure in the line when the supply was shut off to facilitate excavation each day work was carried on. However, in one length two leaks were found 3 feet apart, one about 1/16" by 3/4" and another 1/16" in diameter, while a third in the same 20 foot length was shown later by pressure. Other sections, totalling 90 feet of trench, were opened up and further leakage was indicated and pipe was found to be rough and pitted in representative lengths extending for a distance of 350 feet from the school.

Personal Inspection.

The writer visited the work on the 27th of June. It was noted with the gravity line and school tank full and closed the full gravity pressure from the C.P.R. tank caused an apparent metered leakage of nearly one cubic...
foot per minute. This would account for a charge of about $22.50 per month on leakage alone, which might be expected to soon increase to equal the ordinary charges.

On the 28th pumping and excavation was done so that the pipe was bared and the clay cleared from below for a length of 30 feet. Beside the two repaired sections the whole length of a 20 foot pipe was found to be pitted underneath, one place when measured with calipers was shown to be 1/8" deep. In an adjoining pipe length of ten feet there were indentations or pitting on the top of the pipe, with marks as if an attempt had been made to make nail holes. This pipe was also rough and a hole measuring 1/8" in depth was found. Other lengths had formerly been examined and found pitted.

Conclusions.

It is considered that the whole of the wrought iron section requires replacement by a type of pipe more resistant to the deteriorating action of soil occurring in the district. Transite (Asbestos-Cement) pipe is recommended.

It is believed the galvanized specially wrapped pipe laid for a distance of 300 feet from the tank will prove resistant for some years, as a section of this examined along the line in the station yard showed little, if any, deterioration. A length of 7½ feet of pipe was uncovered on the 28th and personally examined by the writer. The wrapping appeared to be intact and while water was found to be running around the pipe, probably from tank overflow, the pipe surface showed very little evidence of rust, and only one or two slightly rough places could be detected on the under side, and there was no pitting such as was so noticeable on the wrought iron pipe.

Excavation on this line varies greatly from fine sand and cinders at the station to heavy clay and layers of boulders. Of course it may not be necessary to use picks on any of the old trench in redigging; but all the line is deeply buried, mostly over 8½ feet.

Estimates of Cost.

It is estimated that the cost of replacement of the section of the pipe line as outlined above would be as follows:

| Item                                      | Cost     |
|-------------------------------------------|----------|
| 1,100 feet of 2½" Transite, asbestos-Cement, Class 50 pipe @ 43¢ per foot F.O.B. Birtle... | 470.00   |
| 1,100 feet of pipe, cartage to line........ | 10.00    |
| Excavation, laying and refilling.......... |          |
| 1,100 feet @ $1.00 per foot............... | 1100.00  |
| Rental of shovels and pump................ | 20.00    |

Total.......................... $1600.00

(sgd) J.T. Rose.
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle.

Re: Water Supply Line, Birtle Indian Residential School, Birtle, Manitoba.

Referring to your memorandum of the 23rd ultimo to which was attached correspondence you had received from the Acting Director of the Indian Affairs Branch regarding the above, I beg to advise that I am attaching copy of a report prepared by Mr. Rose of Mr. Gow's office at Winnipeg.

From Mr. Rose's report, it will be noted that with the exception of some 300 feet of the pipeline between the C.P.R. water tank and the school, he recommends that the remaining 1,100 feet should be replaced with some type of pipe more resistant to the deteriorating action of soil occurring in the district, and suggests that 4 inch Transite (Asbestos-Cement) Class 50 pipe would be satisfactory. Mr. Rose's estimated cost for material and labour renewing 1,100 feet of pipe in question is $1,600.00.

From the attached report, it is certain that there is a major loss of water occurring in the pipe at present, and that this loss can only increase as the pipe further deteriorates. While not so stated in any information we have on this matter, it is probable that as this water is being taken from a railway tank, the C.P.R. Company may be said to be liable, but it is on information of charges made that Mr. Rose bases his statement in his report that the loss checked by him would amount to a charge of $22.50 per month. As a matter of economy, it would therefore appear essential that this repair work be undertaken. There is also of course the factor of reduced water supply and pressure at the outlet. It is, therefore, recommended that if Indian Affairs Branch have the funds available that repairs to this system should be undertaken along the lines of Mr. Rose's report.

Respectfully submitted,

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the Birtle Indian Residential School dated June 14, 1940.

The playroom and washroom on the girls' side was clean and all plumbing in good condition. The playroom walls are plastered with grey cement. The boiler room is in charge of Mr. Dunn, who has been engineer here for some years. The equipment appears in good condition. Some repair is needed on the outlet provided for taking the ashes from the furnace room. The cordwood has been thrown in at this opening, which is in front of the furnace, instead of dropping it into the fuel room proper. To repair this outlet will require six or eight bags of cement and considerable labour. The repair work should be done this summer and in the future, this outlet should only be used for taking out the ashes. The hoist for lifting the ashes is located in this opening, and sooner or later it will be destroyed if they continue to throw the cordwood in against it. The wood should be put in through the fuel room.

The barns and outbuildings are in good repair but badly in need of painting. Mr. Lockhart stated he had a considerable amount of money to the credit of his school in Toronto. If such is the case, I think some should be used to paint the two main barns. Mr. Lockhart has had no big crops so apparently this accumulation is from the school grant. Other principals do repair work and I see no reason why Mr. Lockhart can not do some too.

Dear Sir:

Since Mr Dunn, who was engineer at the Birtle Residential School, left some time ago, and Mr Beaton took his place I have been dubious about certain parts of the plant functioning properly, especially the Chlorinator. About ten days ago I was up there and although the Chlorinator seemed to be working, I could not taste the chloride in the water. I requested Dr. Edwards, the Medical Officer to send a sample of water to the Provincial Board of Health to be tested. Dr Edwards did this and the water contained Colon Bacilli. Dr Edwards immediately sent for a supply of Anti Typhoid serum to treat all the pupils, and this will be done as soon as the serum arrives.

I went up to the School yesterday and found that the chlorinator was not working at all, and in all probability the pupils and staff have been drinking river water for two weeks which has not been chlorinated. Mr Lockhart, the Principal telephoned to Wallace and Tierman, Winnipeg, requesting them to send up a service man immediately, but they were unable to do so for some days; this firm supplied the chlorinator. As no other man was to be had who understood the plant, I took Mr Dunn, the last engineer, to the School today and had him put the chlorinator in working order, and also adjust other parts of the plant, such as the air compressor, water pump, filter, etc. The Kelvinator is not working but as the Compressor is out of order, Mr Dunn could not repair same. I paid Mr Dunn $5.00 for this work and will send in a voucher for a refund. Owing to some disagreement with the Principal Mr Dunn did not wish to work for the School again.

Mr Beaton the present engineer is leaving in a month and a new man is to take over. Very few engineers understand a plant similar to the one at the school, as chlorinators are not at all common, and though an engineer is quite competent to look after the steam plant, he might do a lot of damage to other parts. A new man should be instructed in such things, before he takes complete charge, or serious damage might take place.
Many changes take place in the staff at this school, though Mr Dunn the late engineer, was there for eight years, and was the oldest member of the staff. If they are to change engineers as often as other members of the staff change, it will be very unsatisfactory.

Yours truly

A.G. Smith

Dear Sir:

Dear Sirs:

We forwarded our statement of February 28th, pointing out to you that $544.01 was outstanding upon our account, and that this covered invoices of June 6th, 1940. In connection with this, please let us advise you that under your file #106-1-5 we have a letter, dated February 28th, from Mr. R. A. Hoey, Superintendent of Welfare and Training, in connection with an invoice of ours of June 6th, 1940, advising us that the account was certified by the Principal of the Birtle Residential School, but that there was an item of $21.44 freight charges, and asking us to forward a receipt from the Railway Company to cover this amount.

It seems unusual that an invoice of June 6th, 1940, should be just referred to us on February 28th, 1941, a matter of nine months afterwards.

In response to your letter, and under date of March 6th, we wrote enclosing the original receipted expense bill to cover the freight charges. Lockhart, Principal of the Indian Residential School, Birtle, and we wish to advise that the invoices were also forwarded at the time that shipment was made.

It would therefore appear to us that the Principal of the School neglected to certify these invoices and forward them to your Department for payment.

Under the circumstances, we are ignoring the typewritten memorandum upon our returned statement, as it would appear that all of this has been attended to within the past month again.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 16th inst regarding paint and equipment for the Birtle Residential School, I am enclosing requisitions for same. The only reason these requisitions were not sent in earlier in the season was that I did not think any money would be available for this work this year, in view of the war.

It is now too late to do outside painting this year, but if the paint is purchased the Principal states that he will have it put on in the spring. The class-rooms can be painted in winter inside.

If this work is done it will save the school a good deal of fuel I am sure, and make the building much more comfortable.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a requisition for repairs to the plant in the Birtle Residential School.

The Kelminator is out of order and they have been using ice in same all winter. The Company will have to send a man to repair same, as there is no local man available who can do this work. I do not know what repairs are required, but think it will cost between $100.00 and $150.00 to put it in good order.

Two new toilet bowls are required, and eight wooden toilet seats. These replacements have always been supplied by the School, but the Principal would like the Department to assume the cost this time.

I would like to be advised what repairs the Department have to assume responsibility for in the School buildings and plant, and what repairs the School have to do at their own expense.

Yours truly,

A.G. Smith

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant the Department approves an expenditure not exceeding $150.00 in repairing the Kelvinator at the Birtle Residential School. In view of the fact that we only have an Acting Principal there at the present time it is expected that you will give personal attention to this repair in order to keep the cost as much below $150.00 as is possible.

You may also purchase 2 new toilet bowls at a total cost of $40.00.

The expenditures authorized in this letter for repairs and improvements at the Birtle School, plus the expenditures already made at this school during the current fiscal year, exhaust the amount provided in the current year's appropriation and it will not be possible to consider any further amount for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment between now and the end of March.

I examined the fire hose at the above school, and recommend that two new ones be supplied at once. The ones in use are 66 feet long without nozzle, brass connection 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" i.e., the supply pipe has an outside thread 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" in diameter. The Chlorinator at the Residential School here has been out of order for some time, and it has been difficult to get a service man to repair same. However a man came up from Brandon today and took the chlorinator apart.

Dear Sir,

As requested, I have again inspected the Birtle School and submit the following short report in connection with the school and the Acting Principal, Mr. Candy.

Mr. Candy advised me he had resigned and expected to leave the school not later than July 31st. I would, however, point out certain improvements since my last visit.

The pupils are more content and appear much happier. The staff has been improved by a new cook, a senior male teacher and a boys' supervisor. The new staff members appear well qualified to do their work and the school discipline has greatly improved.

The frigidaire was not operating. A service man had been to the school twice and made certain repairs but the plant only operated a short time and then stopped. I have made enquiries here concerning the condition of this equipment and the possible cost of putting it in working order. This information when received will be forwarded, and I am hopeful the present unit can be repaired and made ready for use.

The man-hole on the filer broke loose due to the rusting of the rim over which the cover sits. Mr. Candy expected the necessary repairs could be made by the local blacksmith. The repair would necessitate the welding on of a new rim.

Repair work is also needed on the boiler and the local tinsmith and plumber, Mr. Brown, has been requested to submit an estimate on the possible cost of repair parts and the cost of labor.

The old classroom building is now used as a duplex house to accommodate two married members of the staff. The building is very cold in winter and I would recommend that the ceiling be insulated and the walls covered with heavy paper and stuccoed. This would then give comfortable accommodation for two families and the building certainly justifies this extra expense.

The farm work is well along and the crop looks good; but the garden was weedy. Excessive rains made it difficult to get on the land and the weeds got a real start.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA.

The tires on the Birtle Indian School car are about done, and Mr Webb, the Principal, informs me that he cannot even purchase used tires, on account of the category that the car is in.

In my opinion this car is essential, as long as we are able to operate cars at all. In cases of truancy, and at times illness, the car is used for essential purposes. It is also used to convey children to and from the school.

A Minister having two charges, three miles apart, can purchase new tires, providing his tires are done, and a farmer can purchase used tires, so surely an Indian School, which is a Religious Institution, and also farms on an extensive scale, should be entitled to some consideration.

Would you kindly advise me if anything can be done about this, or if they have to do without a car when the present tires are done.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I received your letter No.106-1-5 of Aug. 29th regarding the repairs to the piping and plant at the Birtle Residential School, in which you ask me to explain why the water has damaged the piping and tanks.

I am afraid that I cannot explain this in a satisfactory manner, except to state that the chemical action of the hard water and corrosion have pitted the metal.

In 1935 the pipe line from the school to the barns was partially renewed, and in 1939 the water line from the C.P.R. water tank to the school was renewed. The water pipes in the building seem to be going in the same way and also the tanks, and the outside pipes which have not been replaced. When I am next in Winnipeg I will consult Mr Gow, the engineer in charge of the Dominion Water Power Board, who was in charge of installing the plant at the school, about the present condition of the plant.

To-day I was at the school looking over the work done excavating at the storage tank. The pipe from the outside storage tank to the pump room will have to be renewed, and I will have the local plumber do this. I also found that the iron pipe leading from the pump room to the barn is quite rotten. One of the men excavating struck it with a shovel, and it went to pieces. This was the line that was partially renewed in 1935. I cannot find out just how much iron pipe was left at that time, but I think it was all renewed with the exception of two or three lengths, one of which we have bared.

This will require further excavation to get to the end of the old iron pipe, and it will have to be replaced with galvanized pipe. I request a further accountable advance of $100.00 to proceed with this work. It is impossible to estimate the total cost, as I cannot find out accurately how much old pipe was left in this line; but if it is only two or three lengths, as I am told, this sum should cover it. It would be folly to fill in our present excavation without renewing this pipe, as we would likely have to do it over again at an early date.

I will certainly keep the cost as low as possible, as I do not like spending so much money on such repairs at the present time. The account for plumbing will be over $200.00 when the work is finished, and the Kelvinator repairs will likely amount to $175.00. Repairs to the pump and motor done by the Fairbanks Morse Co. will likely be about $75.00.

Yours truly,

A.G. Smith

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter No.106-1-5,21 the 19th inst requesting a full statement as to why the expenditure on plumbing reached the amount of $169.30, when the sum of $92.50 only was authorized by Mr Phelan in his letter of July 8th 1942.

This only covered damage which was visible from the outside of pipes, and when the pipes were taken down it was found that the damage was much more extensive, and other pipes and fittings had to be replaced. Three small leaks were also repaired in the steam pipes. This account does not cover replacing the water line from the storage tank to the boiler room, or the water line leading to the barns.

In my letter of July 4th requesting the authority I stated that Mr Brown's quotation just covered any visible damage, and that it was quite possible that other replacements might be necessary, when the pipes were taken down and examined. In my letter to you of August 5th I advised you that the plumbing would cost considerable more than the amount authorized.

All the pipes leading out of the Septic tank were completely gone and had to be replaced, in addition to the other damage found in the boiler room.

Dear Sir:

I am forwarding voucher #145, amount $23.50
and voucher #146, amount $32.90 for repairs to the
water pump at the Residential School.

This pump draws water from the reserve
tank into the school and as it had been functioning
only to a very limited extent, was sent to the Fairbanks-
Morse Company for a complete overhaul. After
re-installation the pump still did not give full
service and it was returned to the Fairbanks company
for another checkup. They gave the assurance that
it was in perfect working order, as it would lift
water from a barrel when turned over slowly by hand.

However, it still would not work when connected
with the water main. Excavation was done exposing the
pipe leading from the school to the reserve tank, in
hope of finding a leak allowing the pump to suck air
after it had lowered the level of the water in the tank.

A small leak was found, and pipe and
connection replacements were made, but the pump would
only draw a limited amount of water. It was then
dissembled and the valves found to be badly in need of
trueing. This work was done at the local machine
shop. The Fairbanks Company are allowing a credit
for the cost of the repairs done in Birtle.

Yours truly,

A.G. Smith, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I understand that your application for a new steel tank for the Birtle School has been rejected by the Steel Controller, who suggests that this tank should be replaced with a wood stave tank.

As the school tank is for hot water and carries pressure a wooden stave tank would be useless.

The present tank is pitted inside, and has developed leaks through pin holes, which are of course welded at once. I do not think it probable that a hole will blow out in this tank, but it is possible, and as the tank is overhead in the boiler room, it would be a dangerous thing if it did so, as some of the boys working there might get very badly scalded. There is no manhole in the tank, so that a thorough examination of same is impossible from the inside. I would suggest having the Provincial Boiler Inspector examine this tank and subject it to considerable pressure to make sure that it is not dangerous.

Yours truly,

A form letter from the Indian Affairs Branch dated Feb. 10th 1938, and dealing with instructions re fire facilities states that a principal dissatisfied with fire prevention facilities should so report.

I am enclosing voucher No.132 amount $48.21, in favour of Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co. Ltd Winnipeg for repairs to the motor that operates the pump at the Residential School.

A severe electric storm resulted in the neighbouring Hydro wires being struck, causing either an overload or an underload of current through the motor. The engineer at the School went to the engine room when he heard the crash and found the motor glowing with heat, severely damaged.

The description of such a switch is, 3 pole, 3 phase, 220v magnetic starting switch, with overload release for 3 h.p., 3 phase, 220v motor. The cost would be in the neighbourhood of $15.00.

During the fiscal year 1942-43 the sum of approximately $180.00 was appropriated for the purpose of applying a stucco coat to the employees cottage at the Indian School here. This work was not done as stucco wire could not be obtained, and I advised you a year ago that the money would not be used for that work during that fiscal year.

Stucco wire is still very hard to obtain, but this building could be covered with Insul Brick Siding at a cost of approximately $300.00 for material. This siding is, I am told, very durable and excellent insulation. The school would supply the labour from their funds.

I know that at present there is no money available for repairs to the Birtle School from last years appropriation, but thought it possible that you might at this time have unexpended money available from other accounts.

The Presbyterian Church would like to get this work done as it would make the cottage much more presentable and comfortable. If funds were available I could send in a requisition for material at once.

A.G. Smith

Regarding the plumbing to be renewed at the Birtle Residential School. The return lines from the radiators are both giving out and it will be an expensive job to renew them. The present pipes are black iron and possibly galvanized pipe would last better, and be less costly in the long run. The plumber here thinks it might be possible to use one main pipe for this purpose instead of two as at present. This would mean putting in a larger pipe and fitting the radiators with escape valves. I am writing to the Surveys and Engineering Branch of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau, Winnipeg, for their advice.

The water line from the School building to the barn is also leaking again, though it did not freeze. This whole line was renewed in 1932, and we had trouble with it last spring through frost. The pipe at the barn looked all right when we excavated last spring but we put in some new pipe near the school where there was frost damage. The only thing we can do is to excavate and see what the trouble is. It may just be a faulty union or the damage may be extensive. I request an accountable advance of $150.00 for this work. I beg to refer you to my letter No.15 of 8th April this year, regarding the plumbing at the Birtle Residential School. The return lines from the radiators will have to be renewed. The bottom of the horizontal part of the pipes is eaten and grooved through the action of free oxygen. Last April I wrote to Mr Gow, of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau, Winnipeg, asking for his advice regarding this matter. Recently one of his men called in and looked over the piping, and took a sample of the pipe to Winnipeg. On the 4th inst. I was in Winnipeg and consulted Mr Gow about same. Mr Gow advises replacing the pipe line with galvanized pipe if it is possible to obtain same, and the extra cost is not excessive, but if that is not possible to replace with black iron pipe. To estimate the cost of replacing this pipe is a lot of work, and I can hardly ask the plumber to do so unless we are requesting a tender on the work. I imagine it will cost about $500.00 but that is only a guess of course.

Kindly advise me if the Department are willing to have this work done, and I will then prepare a requisition of material required, and get an estimate of the cost of material and labour from the plumber.

On July 3rd I wrote to you requesting authority to do some work replacing cement around the coping stones and flashing on the roof. Mr Gow advises the use of plastic cement for this work as it will be more durable, though the initial cost will be more. Mr Gow also advised me that the roof would have to be replaced soon, as it was a ten year roof, and was put on fourteen years ago. He also stated that he thought that the large underground water storage tank would soon go, as he did not think it would last more than ten years when it was put in. P.T.O.
The same applies to the filter, some of the water piping, and the pressure water tank in the school.

I will allow for some of this work in the estimates for the coming fiscal year in case it has to be done.

A.G. Smith
Indian Agent

It has been recommended by the Hydro Service Manitoba that the School be checked over for deteriorating wiring. There are an undue number of fuses blowing out, which are due to "wear and tear".
