Would you look into this matter, please.

Yours truly,

Sgd. R. Webb. Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch  
Department of Mines and Resources  
Ottawa

I am enclosing a copy of a letter which I have received from Mr Webb the Principal of the Indian School here regarding the electrical wiring in the building.

I have just interviewed the Hydro Service Man here about the matter, and he states that likely many of the switches are worn and will have to be replaced, but that the actual wiring in the building should be good for years to come. He informs me that Mr W. Walker of Birtle could do this work and that he should have a plan of the wiring. We have no such plan here.

Last year two flood lights were supposed to be installed over the fire escapes but material could not be obtained at that time.

Mr Cruickshanks the Hydro man, could not give me any idea of the possible cost of repairs, but I think $100.00 would cover same and also install the flood lights if material is available.

On the 25th inst I wrote to you regarding the purchase of paint for decorating the school. If funds are not available for purchasing paint and attending to the wiring I think the wiring should come first.

A.G. Smith

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM A. G. HAMILTON, Inspector of INDIAN AGENCIES, dated December 16, 1944, following his inspection of Birtle Residential School, December 6, 1944.

The furnace room was tidy and the equipment all in working condition. The filter, cold water pressure tank and the underground outside tank have given good service; but at any time renewals may be required. These tanks are all badly pitted and just how much longer they will last is a question. The renewal of any one will cost in the neighborhood of five hundred dollars.

The boys half of the infirmary is dark, as there is only one window. This room could be improved if the walls and ceiling were painted a light shade. Mr. Webb planned a special scheme of color for both rooms in the infirmary and had purchased special wall stencils, hoping the Department would furnish the paint; but for some reason the paint specified for this work was omitted. I would recommend that it be supplied, as sick rooms, especially for children, should be bright and cheerful. The requirements are:

5 gals. turquoise, flat wall #10 Silkstone shell pink, #11

The Principal's residence should be repapered downstairs. There is a large hall, a dining-room and a large living room. The paper and labor will cost approximately $75.00. I would recommend Mr. Smith, the Indian Agent at Birtle, be allowed authority to proceed with the work.

The two main barns have been painted and are in good repair. The hog barn, chicken house and machine shed remain to be painted and the paint required will cost about $75.00. This work should be done next year without fail.

The water supply for the Birtle Residential School as you are no doubt aware, is pumped from the Bird Tail River to the C.P.R. water tank, and then purchased from the C.P.R. by the school. The supply is both very unsatisfactory and costly. The water is unfit to drink during most of the winter months, though of course being chlorinated it is safe. The school is at the mercy of the C.P.R. for its water supply as they have given no guarantee that the supply will continue indefinitely. The school pays about $1,000.00 per annum for water I am informed by the Principal, and the Department have paid out large sums to have the water piped from the C.P.R. tank to the school, and to renew the pipe line a few years ago. The water is also very hard on the plumbing and in that way is also costly.

I would suggest that the Department consider the advisability of drilling a deep well sometime after the war, and trying to secure a supply of good water. Since the present school was opened in 1931 I think that the water supply has cost the Church authorities and the Department approximately $15,000.00.

A.G. Smith  
Indian Agent

June 1st, 1945.

Re: INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
BIRTLE, MANITOBA

Referring to your notation on copy of a telegraph dated May 10th from the Acting Director of Indian Affairs, we are in receipt of the following letter dated May 29th from Mr. Cow, which appears to be self-explanatory:

"We have for acknowledgment and attention your letter of May 15th with enclosures relating to the water supply situation at the above-mentioned institution.

An inspection of the water supply situation at this school would not appear necessary at this time but very shortly one of our engineers will be in that district in connection with our regular work and will visit the institution and examine the situation there.

We have no information to the effect that trouble has been experienced with either the storage tank or the pressure tank at the school, rather there is anticipation of trouble particularly in connection with the underground storage tank. This storage tank is 25' long, 78" diameter with heads of 1/8" and shell 1/4" steel, seams stitched, riveted and welded and supplied with a manhole in the shell. Such storage was necessary because of the conditions of the contract for water supply as imposed by the Canadian Pacific Railway from whom the water is obtained. The tank was placed underground for economical reasons after full consideration had been given to the construction of reinforced structure underground and also to the placing of the tank above ground in a suitable enclosed and heated structure. It was estimated that the probable life of the underground tank would be ten years - it has now served for fifteen years. The pressure inside the tank probably never exceeds 10 lbs. The original cost of the storage tank FOR Birtle in 1930 was $660. It is possible that there is now some leakage from the tank without there being any evidence of the same above ground.

The correspondence indicates that the Indian Agent at Birtle has been informed that his Department intends to provide for the drilling of a well at the school in their pasteur programme. Should this drilling be proceeded with and a dependable source of suitable water be obtained, there would appear to be no necessity for the storage reservoir. Under the circumstances it would be advantageous to have the well-drilling programme carried out now and before the reconstruction of the storage reservoir. The present water supply at the school is not only unsatisfactory but expensive and a good supply from a drilled well would offer many advantages over the present supply. However, the Provincial Government records show that very little success has been realised with deep well drilling in the Birtle area and the prospect of securing an adequate source of suitable water in the vicinity of this school must be considered very remote. Even so, we would like to have official notice from the Indian Affairs branch with regard to their plans with respect to the drilling of this well before proceeding with a rather expensive replacement of the storage tank."

You will note that one of the engineers on Mr. Cow's staff will visit the school shortly while engaged on one of his regular trips through that part of the country.

In the meantime, Mr. Cow would like to have more information.

J. M. Wardle, Esq., Director,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing a letter which I have received from Mr. R. Webb regarding repairs to the Birtle Residential School floors and barn. The floors are badly cracked in places. In the Estimates for the current fiscal year I requested that the sum of $360.00 be spent on applying a mastic finish to the main hallway. Many of the treads in the stairs are cracking badly and some have bad holes in them and will have to be repaired during the vacation. The concrete is going in them. I have had some of them filled with concrete but it does not stay in. I am of the opinion that they should also be repaired with some mastic material, but I do not know much about same and am not prepared to make any recommendation without investigating further. I would suggest that Inspector Hamilton take the matter up with Mr. Gow, the Engineer in Winnipeg, or if he has not time or is not in the city, I could do so myself and get an estimate on the job.

Regarding the water bowls in the barn. They flood at times due to variations in the water pressure, which is caused by the amount of water in the C.P.R. tank. Beatty Bros have given Mr. Webb an estimate on new bowls which would do away with that. The cost would be $107.05 for the bowls and connections, plus possibly $75.00 for new overhead piping and labour installing. The present piping in the barn is under the concrete floor. This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 4th referring to the water supply at the above-mentioned institution, and asking for a report on the water supply accompanied by recommendations as requested in your letter of May 16th last.

Since writing you on May 29th last with reference to the water supply, we have had a visit from the Indian Agent, Mr. Smith, and the water supply situation was discussed with him. As mentioned in our letter of May 29th, we still have no information to the effect that the leak has been caused in connection with either the pressure tank or the outside storage tank and so do not consider that either need any repla cement. While the storage tank is 5 feet below ground level, a access to the inside of the tank is readily available by manhole without the necessity of any excavation, thus permitting examination and cleaning when the tank is empty, and the tank can be emptied by gravity at any time.

If and when this storage tank shows signs of becoming unserviceable, it will be advisable to abandon it and erect a new one in a suitably enclosed and heated structure adjacent to the present school building. This would not improve the quality of the water supply but will eliminate some of the difficulty of operation when leaking pipes are discovered or when they must be replaced. However, I think Mr. Smith will agree that this work can be postponed until such time as materials and labour become more plentiful. We will, however, arrange to visit the school in the near future to note the conditions, select a favourable site for the new tank and also examine the conditions of the school in general. Mr. Smith, the Indian Agent, appears to be considerably worried about the cracks throughout many of the floors.

Memorandum:

Mr. D. B. Gow

Re:- Birtle Indian Residential School,
Birtle, Manitoba.

In accordance with your instructions, an inspection was carried out at the above mentioned institution on October 4, 1945. The Indian Agent, Mr. Smith, accompanied the writer during his inspection.

Water Supply System

The school's water supply is obtained from the C.P.R. elevated tank, flowing by gravity to an underground storage tank at the school. This underground storage tank, erected in 1931, is 78 inches in diameter, 25 feet long and was fabricated from 1/4" steel plate with rivetted seams. At the time of erection the tank was estimated to have a life of at least ten years. As the tank is now 14 years old, Mr. Smith thought it might be in need of replacement, although there has been no indication of incipient failure. The exterior of the tank is exposed only at the manhole and shows very little deterioration except only a thin scale of rust is apparent. The engineer of the school had the tank emptied and cleaned it out about a year ago. He said that he tested it all with a hammer then and found no evidence of weakness. It is my opinion that there is no need to replace this tank for some years yet. It would be advisable to have the tank emptied and an inspection made about every two years.

There is no dissatisfaction with the operation of the other elements of the water supply system.

School Roof

There have been no leaks reported in the roof over the school. An inspection was made however and a section of the flashing, about 20 feet long, has separated from the parapet wall about 1/4 inch. The engineer of the school is going to try to repair this section.

Interior Finish

The walls and ceilings are in very good condition, generally. The plaster has spilled off the walls in a few places in the basement but not to any extent and is not due to cracks in the wall structure.

The floors throughout the building are a cement or cement grout finish applied directly to the concrete floor slabs. The cement finish has cracked in all the floors throughout the building. The cracks appear at fairly regular intervals 6' to 8' apart in both directions, making a square pattern.

Three years ago we had a new hot water tank installed in the Birtle Residential School to replace the old one which was done. This tank is 48" in diameter and 10' long on the shell. The shell of the new tank was 1/4" plate and the heads 5/16". This tank has given some trouble all summer and has been welded several times. It cost $552.00 installed, and was bought by the purchasing Agent. At that time the sketch supplied with the requisition called for a tank with 3/8" boiler plate, whereas a tank with 1/4" plate was supplied. On Tuesday the head of this tank blew out, and there was a hole a foot long round the foot of same. Yesterday I had the tank welded so as they would have hot water in the building, but it is not at all safe and will have to be replaced, as it still leaks and may go out again any time. I have warned the Principal to keep all the boys away from it in the meantime. I phoned to Inspector Hamilton about it and he advised me to take it up with the Vulcan Iron Works, Winnipeg. They advise a new tank, and will supply one constructed of 5/16" shell, 3/8" heads, and provided with a manhole, which will permit them to weld the heads to the shell both inside and outside. Also with a manhole the tank can be inspected annually for corrosion. They will also put an extra opening in the tank and supply a relief valve set, which would do away with any danger of having too much pressure in the tank if the cut-out failed to function.

The price they quote on this tank is $330.00 F.O.B. Birtle, Dominion Government Sales Tax of 8% included. The tank can be installed by a local plumber, and I do not think the cost should exceed $75.00.

I think that the tank suggested by the Vulcan Iron
Works Winnipeg would be satisfactory and should give good service, and recommend that same be purchased immediately by telegram.

The present tank had no manhole and was therefore only welded on the outside, and it is the welding and not the plate that is causing the trouble.

I have on hand an accountable advance of $175.00 to pay for painting the school windows, less $3.25 which I paid a man for helping the engineer at the school do some repairs on the roof. I have been unable to get a painter to do this work all summer and it is now too late to have it done until spring. I would suggest using some of this money to have the new tank installed, and returning the balance to the Receiver General for use elsewhere.

A.G. Smith
Indian Agent

One of the water pipes near the underground storage tank at the Birtle Residential School has burst, and they were losing 4000 gallons of water a day, which was coming up through the ground and going into the school boiler room. I have men excavating but have not yet got down to the pipe which is burst, and it may mean a lot of work and expense before they find the right place where the trouble is.

In recent years we have had this trouble almost every winter, when it is most expensive to excavate. Whether it is due to poor piping supplied during the war or not I do not know.

I intend to crib in the piping near to the storage tank so as it will not be so hard to get at it when necessary, and I think that in the end this will prove economical. This will cost about $75.00 or $100.00 for plank. Some plank had to be purchased to crib up the sides on the hole so as to make it safe for the men to work in, as it is so wet and caves in badly. I have no idea how much the excavating will cost, but I have $66.00 left in an accountable advance for repairs to the school which can be used for this purpose.

Kindly advise me by telegram by return if you do not approve of the expenditure for cribbing, as this work has to be done at once to avoid danger from freezing.

A.G. Smith  
Indian Agent

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

Education. At the Birtle Residential School the new Principal seems to be doing well. He is to start teaching wood-work as soon as tools can be obtained, to the older boys. There has been no truancy during the quarter, which is very fortunate in the severe weather. The Indians were bound to take their children home for a Christmas holiday, but due to the fact that there were two cases of chicken pox at the school at the time, they made no trouble about it. They are all keen on having day schools on the Reserve. The children at the school look very healthy and are well clothed, considering the shortage of boots etc. A new boiler was installed at the school to replace one that was put in three years ago, which blew out.

REPORT FOR QUARTER ENDING MARCH 31st.

EDUCATION:

At the Birtle Residential School the boys are now taking classes in wood-work, which is being taught by the Principal. The children are doing well in class-room work, as they spend four and a half days a week in studies. The Principal has had a lot of painting done by the boys with excellent results, and this is brightening up the building a lot. Battle-ship linoleum has been laid in the hospital which is also an improvement. There have only been two truants during the quarter. The children are well clothed considering the shortage of clothing and material, and are well fed, though the parents are continually complaining about the food. The engineer is a good man and keeps the plant and plumbing etc. in good repair.

The water line from the Birtle Residential School to the barns at same has sprung a leak. It is impossible to say where and it may mean a good deal of excavation to find the leak, though I do not anticipate much trouble.

This whole line was renewed eleven years ago, and has given quite a lot of trouble during the last two or three years. Some new piping has been put in and we know where it is which will help. If it can be avoided I am not in favour of renewing the line this year on account of the scarcity of labour and the high wages prevailing.

As soon as I can get two men to excavate I will start on this work, and request an accountable advance of $150.00 to pay for labour.

I am pleased to say that the school windows have been painted.

Dear Sir:

I understand that the Dominion Government will soon be asking for tenders for the erection of Indian Schools at Rostock, Sask., St. Paul de Metis, Alberta, and Birtle, Manitoba. I wish to make application for the position of clerk of the works on one of these buildings.

I have had forty years experience in the building business, having pursued it in Manitoba and Saskatchewan. I am at present clerk of the works for the Regina General Hospital Board, on a Nurses'

I beg to give you the following information with reference to the appointment of Inspector of Construction for the new Birtle Indian Residential School. On June 6th a letter was written to the Civil Service Commission advising that tenders were being invited for the new Birtle School and that they closed on the 30th day of the month, and asking them to advertise the position of Inspector of Construction.

As a result of this advertisement only one application was received, and the applicant did not possess the necessary qualifications.

On August 5th the Civil Service Commission advised that they were again advertising the position, and this time the advertisement appeared in the Winnipeg papers in addition to Birtle. As a result of this advertisement 21 applications were received. From this list two were selected who were thought to possess the required qualifications and a telegram is being sent today to Mr. John R. Bunn, asking him to arrange with H.H. Matthews, District Resident Architect of the Department of Public Works, to interview both parties and wire a recommendation to the Department.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Thomas G. Murphy -

Re Inspection Birtle Indian Residential School.

I beg to give you full information with reference to the inspection of the construction work on the new Birtle Indian residential school. On June 6th, the Civil Service Commission was informed that we were inviting tenders for this work and that they closed on the 30th, June. We asked them to advertise the position 'Inspector of Construction'. The position was advertised locally, the competition closing on July 15th. A Board meeting was held July 24th, when it was found there was only one applicant who did not possess the necessary qualifications. The Civil Service Commission on August 5th, advised us that they were again advertising the position in Winnipeg as well as in Birtle. This competition closed on August 23rd. As a result of this advertisement twenty-one applications were received. Two, residents of Winnipeg, have been selected by the Board and I am arranging to have a report from the District Residential Architect of the Department of Public Works, who has been asked to recommend one of these men.

The Claydon Company being the lowest tenderer was advised by me, with the authority of the then Superintendent General, on July 3rd, that their
tender would be accepted and they might proceed with the work. Foreseeing that there would be delay in the appointment of an Inspector of Construction the Department on July 8th, wrote Mr. William Swan, Architect of Punnichy, who is Inspector of Construction at the Muscowequan residential school, asking him to take complete charge of this work, and on locating the building on the site to communicate with the Acting District Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch in Winnipeg, as they had already prepared a plan of the property in order to arrange for a proper lay-out for the water supply and sewage disposal systems. Mr. Swan visited the work on the 16th and 30th July and on the 7th, 19th, and 27th August.

September 6th,

The District Residential Architect, Winnipeg, has highly recommended one of the applicants, Mr. David Henderson, and I have today wired Mr. Henderson instructing him to commence his duties immediately.

The roof of the school is leaking in places, and some damage was done during a very heavy rain we had. I will have this repaired with asphalt or pitch as soon as possible, without further authority. I do not think the cost will exceed $100.00.

I have received your letter No.106-1-5 (WT 1) of the 5th inst. regarding vouchers No.350 and 352 which are enclosed.

My intentions were to write a letter of explanation to forward with the vouchers in the first place, and I regret that I neglected doing this.

The root house has cost more for material and labour than I figured on. The site turned out to be very stony when the sod was taken off, and it has cost $52.00 for excavation; the gravel pit where I figured on obtaining gravel at a reasonable cost was full of water and I had to have the gravel hauled 12 miles at a cost of $2.75 per yard. Gravel cost $85.24, which was paid from the advance of $300.00, and $52.00 for excavation, was also paid from the advance, in addition to the $50.00 paid for labour and deducted from the amount of the enclosed vouchers. This leaves a balance of $67.76 left in the Agency account to the credit of the advance. I have still to pay for filling in around the root house and other sundry accounts from the advance, hence the enclosed vouchers.

The actual carpenter work also cost more than I expected. This is the first root house that I have ever had built, and I certainly did not allow enough for labour, gravel etc.

A.G. Smith  
Indian Agent
Birtle Manitoba
10th November 1947

Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines and Resources
Ottawa

There was a class-room at the old Birtle Residential School, which was built about 1924-25. When the new school was built this class-room was converted into a cottage for employees of the school, and now two families live in same. One side was made into four rooms which are comfortable, and well laid out. The other side was divided very poorly, as there is a lot of waste room, and no door at the back for the family residing in that portion of the building. Some of the rooms are more or less fire traps on that account.

For a sum not exceeding two hundred dollars, the partitions could be moved, utilizing the waste room, and providing a back door and porch. A certain amount of material would be required, but it is impossible to requisition for the exact amount, as it would depend on circumstances. I do not think that the material would cost over $50.00.

One employee is moving out of the house soon, as he is leaving the staff, and the work should be done before the new occupant moves in.

Kindly advise me if you have money available to proceed with the alterations, and approve of same.

A.G. Smith
Indian Agent

Repairs to roof, Birtle Resid. School.

Last June, during the very heavy rains, parts of the roof of the Residential School were found to be leaking, and authority was given for $100.00 for repairs. A quantity of roofing tar was purchased, but it was possible to repair only the leaky places.

Mr. Linton, of A.B.C. Roofing Co. Winnipeg, has inspected the roof, and reports that the portions over the principal's residence, and the boys' dormitory require re-roofing, and his company will undertake the work, supplying material and labour for $125.00. This does not include gravel.

He reports that the main roof requires only minor attention, which can be done by the school staff.

The roofing company are working in the neighbourhood, and would be available for this job next week. In the absence of Mr. Smith, I have authorized the work to be done, since material must be ordered at once.

A. Nicholson,

Re: Water System, Birtle Residential School, Manitoba.

I am enclosing copies of radiogram and letter received from the Engineering and Construction Division of our department at Ottawa with respect to the water system at the Birtle Indian Residential School. It will be noted from this correspondence that this office was asked to co-operate with advice in connection with any repair work which should be carried out at the institution.

Two engineers of this office have just returned from an inspection of conditions at the Birtle Indian School and they discussed the situation there with Messrs. Hamilton and Russell and also the engineer of the school. It was impossible to locate the source of the leakage and it may necessitate considerable excavation work in order to locate the exact spot of leakage so that the defective parts can be replaced. There is no labour supply at Birtle or in the immediate vicinity for the carrying out of such work. Our engineers report that the school authorities have been compelled to seep into the drain in the pump room down to the drain in the boiler room. It is also reported that water is seeping up through the floor of the boiler room into the ash pits of the furnace and it is this aspect of the situation which is considered most serious. The cost of water is reported to have increased from a monthly average of about $45.00 to a monthly average of $90.00 for the month of January. Our engineers are of the opinion that it is advisable to proceed immediately with repairs so as to overcome the excessive leakage which is now occurring.

They were instructed to and did discuss with Messrs. Neale, Stothard and Chapman of Brandon as to whether or not that firm could undertake the necessary repair work. Mr. Stothard informed our engineers that they were able to undertake this work at once and could arrange to send up laborers and pipe fitters to do the necessary excavation and repair work. I understand accommodation for the men is available at the Birtle Indian School. Mr. Hamilton also advised our engineers that he had authority to proceed on any repair work which was considered necessary. The writer would suggest, therefore, that you write to Messrs. Re: Birtle Residential School.

All the washing at this school is done in the large washing machine. Mr. Rusaw points out that this arrangement is not satisfactory nor economical. He requests that they be supplied with a household electric washing machine.

The big machine is too severe on the fine linens and ladies wear. It also requires more soap and washing powder because in the big machine a large amount of water is required. It was also pointed out that the present necessity of all using the large washing machine has been a constant complaint from the ladies on the staff. They claim it is too hard on the finer materials and as the big machine washes very dirty clothes, sometimes these finer clothes are discolored. I feel the request is reasonable and would recommend the purchase.

A.G. Hamilton,
Superintendent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Repairs to Equipment, Birtle School.

The wood ends in the washing machine at the school show marked signs of decay, in fact the wood can be picked out in places by ones finger nail. How long this machine will last I cannot say and I doubt if it can be repaired. It was supplied by the Canadian Laundry Machinery Co. Ltd., Toronto, Serial No. 1215 M7216.

I would also draw the Department's attention to the fact that the upright high pressure boiler has not been in use for over a year. I understand it is considered unsafe. Mr. Rusaw claims that since the boiler has not been in use the laundry work has been more difficult. There is often insufficient hot water and drying the clothes in winter is a real problem. The dryer is operated by steam and so has been useless. This equipment should be checked by experts and repaired or replaced.

A.G. Hamilton,
Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Repairs Birtle Residential School.

I am enclosing a list of repairs to order from the Fairbanks Morse Co. for the water pump at the school. There is no authority for this but it is an emergent repair and they should be ordered at once.

The leak in the water system was in the big storage tank, in a place where it was fitted inside and out. The local blacksmith has put a patch on same. This tank will have to be renewed during the summer I think. It is too expensive to repair when it takes so long to locate the leak, and you cannot tell how long it will be before it goes through some other place, and it all has to be done again.

The flues in the horizontal boiler are leaking and will likely have to be renewed. It is possible that they might last for a while if rolled, but very doubtful. To install new flues will cost approximately $225.00. The local blacksmith put new flues in this boiler ten years ago, so they have lasted well. Before that time they were renewed every three or four years. He put in heavy locomotive flues. He would not give me a definite price on same as he does not know the cost of flues at present. Authority should be obtained to have this work done immediately as the boiler cannot be used now.

I should have stated that there is also a leak in the water line to the barn but they have not located it. In June that line should be renewed. There is no use digging anymore at present as two men might dig for a month and then not find it. The main leak was in the tank.

Yours very truly,

(Signed) A.G. Smith.
Asst. Indian Agency.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS & DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Re: Birtle Indian Residential School

I desire to refer to our memorandum of April 30th and your reply of May 6th regarding the water system at the above school. In your memorandum you stated that Mr. Perrie had been instructed to make an investigation at the earliest possible date and submit a report.

We have not yet received this report, but Indian Superintendent Hamilton has written us as follows in a letter dated July 6th:

"I wish again to bring to the attention of the Department, the need for repairing and renewing the water line and tank at the above school. The tank should be renewed also the pipe line from the school to the barn. The water could be cut off now that the school is closed and the repair work done at a much less cost than during 20 below weather.

We would appreciate hearing from you in regard to the above.

Re: High Pressure Boiler,
Birtle Indian Residential School,
Birtle, Manitoba.

Further to our memorandum of May 2nd in connection with the above, you are advised that we are in receipt of a report from Mr. Perrie with reference to the above.

The report states that the vertical high pressure boiler has been condemned by the Provincial Boiler Inspector, as it has reached the stage of deterioration where it is not possible to carry out satisfactory repairs.

This boiler was installed to supply steam to the washer and drier only. The fireman advised Mr. Perrie that while the boiler was easy to stoke, it was always difficult to maintain a satisfactory operating pressure.

From data supplied in Mr. Perrie's report, it can be deduced that the boiler is approximately 6 horsepower. The theoretical requirements to serve the washer and drier do not exceed 6 horsepower, but it is not practicable to size a boiler of this kind within such close limits. There is very little reserve steam storage space and as soon as the steam is turned on, the pressure drops to a point where it is ineffective.

After fully considering the requirements, it is recommended that a new vertical high pressure boiler having a capacity of at least 12 horsepower and built for 100 lbs. per square inch working pressure, be purchased and installed. It is also recommended that a condensation barrel of approximately 75 gallon capacity be provided, together with a return line with inverted bucket trap from the drier. This return line to be extended to the condensation barrel; the object being to avoid the use of 100% raw make-up water. A new injector should be supplied as part of this equipment.

The new high pressure boiler should be a vertical type, equal to that made by E. Leonard and Sons, rated at 13 horsepower, complete with mountings and base. The approximate cost of this installation will be $1,200.00.

When approval is given, we will prepare a detailed list of the equipment from which a purchase order can be made.

Mr. Perrie was also asked to report on the water situation at this school. When this report has been received and analyzed, you will be further advised.

MEMORANDUM

Re Water System, Birtle Indian Residential School, Birtle, Man.

Referring to the memorandum from Indian Affairs dated April 30, 1949, on the above subject, we are now in receipt of the following from Mr. Perrie:

"In accordance with your letter of May 5, 1949, an investigation of the water supply system at this school has been made and I have to report as follows:

The source of the school water supply is the nearby elevated water tank of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company. From this tank the water flows by gravity to an underground storage tank which is located just outside the school building and adjacent to the boiler room. The water is pumped from the supply tank through the school water system and to the barn.

The gravity supply line from the C.P.R. tank is reported to have been renewed last year and it can be assumed that this line is now in good condition but leaks have developed in the underground storage tank at the school and it is suspected that the supply line from the pump to the barn is also leaking.

The supply tank at the school is 25' in length with a diameter of 78" and was fabricated from 4" steel plate. It was erected in 1931 and its expected life when buried underground would be not more than ten years from the time of its installation. This tank was leaking last year and was presumed to have been repaired when a steel plate was welded over the area through which the water was leaking at the time the repair was made.

At the time of my inspection the tank was full of water and it was not convenient to drain the tank at that time in order to inspect its interior. However, it is my experience that once a tank of this kind, with the life that this one has had, develops one leak it can safely be concluded that more will follow and it is a waste of time and money to begin patching the holes as they develop. This tank should therefore be replaced immediately.

I am unable to furnish you with an estimate covering the cost of a new tank but this information can no doubt be readily obtained from the Architectural Branch of the Division, which branch is likely installing

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa."

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6253, File 575-5, part 9)
similar tanks in new schools as they are built. A blueprint copy of a plan, prepared in the Winnipeg District Office, showing the tank dimensions is attached hereto. In the event that a new tank is to be installed in accordance with the old plan, the cost of transportation, installation and the reconstruction of the timber manhole would be approximately $1,000.00.

Although the initial cost would be higher, I am of the opinion that instead of burying the new tank in the ground as at present it would, over a period of years, be more economical to install the tank in a chamber of its own immediately adjacent to the school boiler room. This would place the tank where it would be open to inspection at all times and by keeping the exterior painted the life of the tank would be prolonged indefinitely. Such a chamber could no doubt be readily designed by the Architectural Branch of the Division.

In order to determine the extent, if any, of the leaks in the line from the school to the barn, it will be necessary to dig up the present line at considerable expense. I am of the opinion that it may be found that the suspicion that this line is leaking may prove to be unfounded when a new supply tank is installed and the leaks stopped at that point. It is therefore recommended that the matter of digging up the supply line to the barn be left until the new tank is installed."

From the above we estimate that the cost of replacing the tank would amount to approximately $2,750.00 if buried in the same manner as the present tank. However, if we decide to place the new tank in a special chamber, it is likely that the cost might reach an additional $750.00.

Before we can decide definitely whether to put the tank into a separate chamber, we need more local information. In the meantime, if Indian Affairs will transfer $3,500.00, we will arrange to proceed with the project.

Dear Sir:

Having just visited Birtle Indian Residential School, I am writing you regarding some matters which are causing me great concern. I know they are matters, not directly in your department and yet because they have to do with the welfare of the children, I feel they should be of concern to you too.

For some months Mr. Rusaw has been trying to get some attention and action regarding certain necessary repairs and replacements:
1. Replacement of the outside water supply storage tank.
2. Renewal of waterline to the barn from the main building.
3. Replacement of the large washing machine.

Mr. Rusaw is of the opinion that all of these replacements should be made immediately and I heartily agree with him. The large washing machine is completely broken down and the laundry is being done in a small machine which is the size used in the ordinary home. Yesterday, the lady in charge of the laundry, told me that she had had to do 28 washings in the little machine in order to wash the sheets from the children's beds. This of course cannot continue. The little machine is not built for this type of work, neither can we expect to keep a laundry matron in our employ under these conditions.

So far as the replacements to the water supply storage tank and the renewal of the waterline are concerned, these repairs were recommended after a survey in May by Mr. Perrie, Regional Engineer at Regina, Lands and Development Service Branch. Mr. Davis, Regional Supervisor of Manitoba and Mr. Hamilton, Superintendent at Portage la Prairie, are both aware of these very much needed repairs. We are at a loss to understand why no action has been taken. Mr. Rusaw and Mr. Findlay, the engineer, are greatly disturbed and are anxious that all repair work be done before winter.
Would you be good enough, Colonel Neary, to see that some immediate action be taken. As I mentioned at the beginning of this letter, I am concerned not only for the sake of the staff but for the welfare of the children and I do think these repairs and replacements are most necessary.

Hoping to have a favourable reply, I remain,

Dear Sir,

Having been asked by Inspector Jackson to report on the value of the north east quarter of section five tp. seventeen range twenty & seven west of first principal meridian we beg leave to submit the following:

The land is situated immediately to the east of the school site. The road allowance between the two properties has never been used and as the cost of a good grade would be very great it is not likely to be used for many years to come. The property is therefore conveniently situated to the school site. The Bird Tail river runs almost through the centre of the property giving it a plentiful water supply. A considerable portion is wooded with poplar, at the present time about six hundred cords could be cut on it. The value of this standing is about $600. What is not wooded has good grass and makes good natural pasture. This is about all that can be said in favor of this land. The hillsides on the north are steep and cut with deep ravines and besides this are very stony. The south side is not so steep but is very stony. While some small fields could be broken up we do not think this land could be brought under cultivation without costing more than it is worth. By using this land in its natural state it should pasture about thirty head of cattle and should be worth for our purposes from one hundred to two hundred dollars per year. readily and probably would not bring ten dollars an acre but I should think that being free from taxes as the property of the government it should be worth about fifteen for this purpose.

The lots lying north of the school site have little value for building or agriculture. The ground is very stony. It would have some value for us as it would give the whole block which we could improve of $165 as suited our purposes.

The part south of the track is stony. The part north of the track consisting of about one hundred acres is first class land.

It is fenced but not otherwise improved. It has no surface water. The arable land is about half a mile from the school, by an easy road. This land belongs to Mr. John Patterson Birtle and can be bought at from thirty five to forty dollars an acre.

Sir,

Your letter No.116,624-1 of date the 2nd.instant,received and in reply. On Monday the 7th.I went up to Birtle and have returned this morning,after looking fully into the subject of your communication. The Presbyterian Church have a very large amount of money invested in the Birtle Indian School,and no suitable land for farming adjacent to the school. The 28 acres mentioned in my letter of the 16th.ultimo does not help them out very much as they have had the use of it for years. This school being so far away from a good vegetable market can not make very much from a small farm,and must have some good arable land close to the school if they wish to farm on a large scale and make institution profitable.

After looking carefully into the matter,and talking over everything in connection,with the Principal,and Farmer,of the Birtle School,I have come to the conclusion that the best solution would be the purchase of a half section which can be bought,and which adjoin the present school grounds.

The north west quarter of section 5 is not suitable for grain or root farming,and its use to the school would be for the pasture of sheep,cattle,& horses. I went over a large part of this quarter section with Mr.Iverach,on the afternoon of the 7th.and as there is no snow in this part of Manitoba at the present time there was no obstacle to our making an estimate as to the value of the property. On the morning of the 8th. I got Mr.Iverach and the farmer Mr.Perry,who is a practical farmer to go all over the quarter again and I send you their signed report on same. This is a very rough and broken quarter section,the north half is about 150 feet higher than the south 80 acres,and with a steep hill. The whole quarter is covered thickly with stone &
and the south half is very bad. The main value to the school is its proximity and its use as a pasture for sheep, cattle, and horses, and the never failing supply of water in the river. There is also say about 5 or 600 cords of small standing poplar wood worth at least $1.00 a cord in the bush. I would estimate the value of this property to the school at $15.00 per acre. I drove over the S.W. ¼ of section 8 which immediately adjoins the ½ in 5 on the north, and for the purpose of grain and root farming it would be just what the school wants, as there is about 100 acres of virgin soil without stone. There is some bush and brush on this 100 acres, but it could all be broken up with a small expense. The portion of this ½ south of the C.P.R. and adjoining 5 is of little use except for pasture. This quarter can be bought for about $35.00 an acre, or a trade might be made for the quarter section owned by the Presbyterian Church at say a difference of fifteen dollars an acre, this Church owned land is too far away from the school for profitable working. The lots shown on the sketch sent me 211 to 214 belonging to the Railway Co. are of no particular value except to square up the property, as they are a bed of surface stone, and I would advise that no higher than $20.00 an acre be paid for these blocks and streets. Dear Mr. Scott:

Referring to your letter No. 106-1-9 of October 16th last, and mine of November 8th, I beg to inform you that I have now obtained a price from the Minister of Agriculture of the Manitoba Government on the Experimental Farm at Birtle. In addition to the price on the buildings, property and fencing, they have submitted prices on the implements, stock, lighting plant, etc., and the total amounts to $38,856.85. This also includes a quantity of feed and seed of a high grade, which in itself amounts to $5619.00.

My own opinion is that it would be a wonderful thing for our Department if we could take over this stock in the event of a purchase of the property being made. The price which has been placed on the stock is just about what we would expect to pay for ordinary grade cattle, and these are by no means grade cattle, three of them being pedigreed and the others eligible for pedigree. Details in connection with the farm were fully set out in my report of the 8th November. I may say that the machinery is all in good shape.

-I believe-

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
I believe that the services of the man who has been operating this farm could be retained at a reasonable figure, and he could carry on under the supervision of the School Principal, or in other words, act as Farming Instructor.

The Department would be called upon to erect the main school building, and if it were felt that funds could not be found to provide a Principal's residence just now, I believe that the existing house could be utilized for that purpose for a year or two.

In my opinion, this is an excellent opportunity to obtain a splendid property, and if we could obtain it for between $35,000 and $35,000 the price I consider would be low. Mr. Prefontaine is very anxious to get this transaction closed if the Department has any idea of purchasing, so that he will be able to bring the matter before the next session of the legislature, which opens in about a month's time. Of course, the session will continue for some time after it is opened.

I should be glad if you would give this matter your consideration. I think I have given you all the information I possibly can in regard to it. An Inventory of the property and equipment is herewith enclosed.

Yours very truly,

Wm. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT.

RE: New Site for Birtle Indian Residential School.

I have read Mr. Commissioner Graham's letter concerning the Manitoba Government's offer to sell their demonstration farm near Birtle, and I have studied the inventory showing the land, buildings, live stock, implements and other chattels. At the outset, I wish to concur in Mr. Graham's remarks that here is an excellent opportunity to obtain a splendid property.

The selection of the farm by the Manitoba Government for an experimental station is sufficient evidence of the quality of the land. The size of the property - 320 acres - is suitable for our purpose. The buildings, stock, implements, etc., are very similar to what is required for an Indian residential school. No doubt, a suitable site can be found for a main building. There is nothing to indicate that the water supply would be inadequate for our purposes; but I recommend enquiries in this regard be made at once.

The price set by the Manitoba Government is divisible as follows:

- Land (320 a.) $9,590.00
- Buildings $10,545.00
- Live stock $5,096.75
- Agricultural implements $4,808.50
- Light and water supply $1,345.00
- Fence $1,625.00
- Crop and seed $5,619.50
- Miscellaneous $260.00

Total: $38,886.85

The inventory shows that there are more agricultural implements, live stock and seed grain on the property than the Department needs for the Birtle Indian Residential School. The prices placed on these items total nearly $16,000.00. I believe the following are surplus to our requirements and should either not be acquired or sold after purchase:

- Live stock:
  - 4 horses $500
  - 4 steers and 5 cows $500
  - 4 calves " 1 bull $400
  - 94 sheep $1,200
  - 18 hogs $250
  - Agricultural implements (estimated) $1,000.00
- Crop (estimated) $4,000.00
- Lighting plant $500.00
- Miscellaneous equipment (the apiary) $80.00

Total: $8,550.00

This suggests...
This suggests that the net cost of the property to this Department would be approximately $30,000.00, which leads me to urge that the Manitoba Government's offer be favourably considered.

It is interesting to compare this figure with the cost of establishing the Chapleau and Portage Indian Residential Schools. In the case of these institutions, property was purchased and outbuildings, live stock and agricultural equipment were provided. In neither case is there a special residence for the principal. Over $27,000 has been expended at Chapleau for these purposes and the farm is not nearly as desirable as the one now under consideration. The farm, the outbuildings and agricultural equipment at the Portage School have cost the Department over $49,000.

The property offered by the Manitoba Government appears to be very suitable for the Birtle Indian Residential School. The farm is a going concern—a big asset to the school management. The cost is well within the expenditure usually necessary in similar cases, and I wish to recommend the purchase to your favourable consideration.

Russell Heirier
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

Referring to your letter No. 106-1-9 dated the 23rd ultimo, I have been giving the matter of the proposed new Birtle Indian Residential School site serious consideration and I believe that the Department would be well advised to build the new school on the Waywayseecappo Reserve where there is excellent farming, pasturage and hay lands. I am satisfied that there would be no difficulty in obtaining the consent of the Indians of the Waywayseecappo Band to set aside the necessary land required for school purposes. Placing the school on this reserve would bring it to a more central location for the Indians. The railway runs through the north east corner of the reserve and there would be direct railway connection with the Keesakowenin and Rolling River Reserves, and as it is hoped that we may in time induce these bands to amalgamate with and move to the Waywayseecappo Reserve, the arrangement would be very satisfactory for the future. Apart from this, I feel that the move would be a good one. There is no benefit to be derived by having the school located near the Town of Birtle, and I think the new location would be conducive to more efficient work. The only reserve affected would be the Birdtail and it would make very little difference to them. They are only a small band.

I would be glad if you would give this matter consideration and, in the event of it receiving your approval, I would immediately take steps to have the location on the reserve selected and make arrangements with the Indians.

Dear Mr. Currie:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, with reference to the building programme for the Birtle Indian Residential School.

A few days ago, Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham's recommendation, that a site be selected on the Saywayescappo Reserve, was approved and Mr. Graham was requested to have you accompany whatever officer made the selection of the farm and building site. I believe the opposition you anticipate from the other Indian reserves would be but temporary, and, if necessary, the Department would enforce the compulsory clauses of the Indian Act. The Saywayescappo Reserve, from the Department's standpoint, has many advantages. There would be practically no expenditure for the site and farm. It would be on the line of railway which has direct railway connection with the Keesekosomin and Rolling River Reserves. Further, excellent agricultural land can be secured. I may add, however, that no definite decision will be made until after the Department receives Mr. Graham's report.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I have to acknowledge Departmental letter, or the 25th Inst., No. 106-1-15. Advising that it was approved, that a site be selected for the Birtle Residential New School on the Reserve at Waywayseecappo. The principal reason, apparently, for the selection of this site being, "That practically there would be no expenditure for the site or farm." My opinion is that it is expensive at the price stated.

I beg to point out a few facts. First, the portion of the Reserve where the Indians of that Band desire the new school located has not an acre of land under cultivation. It will take a lot of money and years of time to develop a farm there that will be revenue producing. Secondly, it is likely to cost hundreds of dollars to get a water supply, of questionable quality. In fact, there is no assurance that an adequate supply is obtainable. In the third place while the Ry. runs through the property giving a tri-weekly service there is no town of any size nearer than Birtle about 25 miles distant. True, the Birdtail Siding is only a mile away, it has one country store and two elevators, Rossburn and Angusville two tiny villages are each about seven miles distant. There the nearest Doctors live, to these places with mud roads over which for many months of every year an Auto cannot travel. This place is certainly out of the world, hid in a place where it will never be seen by the public. A place where it is going to be hard to retain a Staff. A Staff of an Indian School require a change after being with Indian Children.

day after day, when their half day off, or other times when off duty comes round, there should be some place where they might go to make a little change. Such a change is not to be found near the Reserve. In fact the vicinity of the Waywayseecappo Reserve is just a little "Hell." It is only a pity the poor Indian has to associate and live in such surroundings. It is surrounded by a Galician settlement. And these people are a curse to our people. Peddling bootleg whiskey and every demoralizing evil you can think of. Court cases are constantly going on. As many as eight cases sometimes in an afternoon. The Mounted Police are never out of a job in that community. To my mind it will be a serious blunder if our new school is moved to such a place. It is only by getting our children away from such surroundings having them here, under our care and training until their character is developed that we can ever hope to uplift and improve the Race.

Aside from this foreign settlement, there is sure to be considerable trouble with young unmarried Indian men hanging about the school trying to make love to the girls. I found this difficulty at Alberni where the School was close to the Reserve. The price one must pay for safety is close constant vigilance night and day. As I mentioned in my former letter, the Indians of the Rolling River and the Keesekoonenin Reserve are strongly opposed to the new school being built on the Waywayseecappo Reserve and to this you say the Department will compel these Indians to send their children to the new school, quite so, but the coercion will only increase their bitterness and antagonism. We cannot forget that we are trying to do mission work with these people and to do effective work must have their friendship and everything that antagonizes only serves to make the work the harder. Their antagonism will tend to cause them to complain about any little thing, about the school, that displeases them. To my mind harmony will prevail if a site is chosen away from any of the Reserves. And as Birtle has for so long been their educational centre I see no cause for a change from this district.

Since I have known that the deal we were trying to put thru with the Provincial Government for their Demonstration Farm had fallen through I have been looking about for a suitable site, to suggest to the Indian Department. Such a site I have found. It belongs to one Mr. T. Edmunson, it is four miles north of Birtle. The Demonstration Farm was three miles south. Mr. Edmunson has a section of land on the main Provincial Highway, Winnipeg to Edmonton. About half of the section is under cultivation, 87 acres summer fallowed last year. This is a good clean farm, well suited for mixed farming. Has a fine stone house with bath, a small house for his farmer, a barn fair condition, it will not meet our need but certainly has considerable value, there are about ten portable graineries. And this place has the four things I specially had in mind in looking for a good location. Plenty of good land for agriculture, a good building site, good drainage, and last and most important an abundant supply of good water. This water supply cannot be valued, for our purpose, less than $5000.00. It is of choice quality. This farm is as close to Foxwarren as it is to Birtle. Here we are on the C.P. Ry., Winnipeg -- Edmonton Br., and have two trains daily each way. Mr. Edmunson is asking $25.00 an acre for this property. To my mind for
our purpose, this is a snap. This is a farm Mr Edmunson has made ample to retire on. And would be a revenue producer from the very start. This property is slightly rolling, and I have picked out a site that would be a commanding situation for the new school, slightly higher than the highway or any of the surrounding district, and would admirably lend itself to making the school on such a site an imposing structure. Something that would be a real attraction on this much travelled Provincial Highway.

Taking into consideration, the over 300 acres under cultivation, the buildings, the water supply, the roads, the convenience of the Ry., the Doctor, and other advantages. This property is cheaper at Mr Edmunsons price than the Indian Reserve is as a gift, I have no doubt in the world if the Department will send out a man and let me show him over the two properties, Such a man will concur in what I have placed before you in this letter. I have carefully gone over both locations. What I tell you is no heresay. And I believe my experience both as Principal of an Indian School and as a farmer enables me to judge aright in this matter.

One matter "I nearly overlooked, it is or slight consideration. Is High school opportunities for a few of our pupils At present we have one girl doing splendid in Birtle High school. Birtle is a consolidated school district. From the site I have suggested our Pupils might continue to attend Birtle High School and still reside in the Indian Residential School. This property is in the Birtle Consolidated School area, and the school vans convey pupils back and forth. This advantage does not exist at the proposed Reserve site.

Perhaps I may appear to be putting my views rather strong. But I cannot help being interested in this matter. A year ago after the site had been chosen and the new school at Kenora, for our Church had been started, I was offered the Principalship of that new School. But I turned it down and prefered to wait just for the one reason that I wished to see the new Birtle School built such, that I would like to continue to carry on in.

I remember Dr. Scott what you said in 1927 when you were at Birtle, "That you did not want any mistake made in the site chosen" I have always kept this in mind. I was satisfied had we secured the Demonstration Farm no mistake would have been made, I am just as satisfied now that Mr Edmunsons place will give perfect satisfaction.

I beg to refer to Department's letter of the 19th ultimo, and also to a telegram dated the 4th May with reference to a site for the proposed Indian Residential School to replace the one that is now at Birtle. I note from your telegram that the Church authorities and the Rev. Mr. Currie informed me that the opposition to building on the reserve came from Toronto, and that he, personally, was more or less indifferent about the matter. The reason for not wishing to have the school on the reserve is that it would be in too close proximity to the Indians. This to my mind is not a good and sufficient reason. As a matter of fact it has been the policy of the Department ever since I can remember to build most of the Indian schools on the reserves. Within the last four or five years we have built two schools on the Blood Reserve, two on the Blackfoot, one on Keesekoosne, two on Onion Lake, and are about to build another on Gordon's, so that as far as our policy is concerned we would only be adhering to it in building on the reserve. It rests entirely with the management of a school as to whether the Indians will be allowed to make themselves a nuisance by coming around the place. COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., May 25th, 1929.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, and have noted the contents. I will take steps at the earliest possible date to try and locate a suitable improved farm for the Birtle School.

I would point out, however, that it is most dangerous to select a farm at this particular season. Manitoba, as you know, is, in some parts, infested with weeds; in fact, there are districts where the farmers are abandoning their farms, because they cannot make a living on them owing to the weeds, and to buy a farm on the word of any owner would be a great mistake. It would be most difficult, in fact, impossible, for a person to go this week, for instance, and see for himself whether the land is infested with weeds. The weeds have not all started to grow yet, and some of the worst infested farms in the country would look all right in the early spring. It is to avoid this that I am asking that I delay the matter of going to select a farm for at least two weeks. I appreciate thoroughly the fact that the season is advancing and that the choice must be made without delay. However, if you are satisfied that I should take a chance and proceed at once and not wait until the weeds develop, I will do so. I am merely suggesting that the other course be followed. I will try to select a farm closer to the town, probably between the Waywayseecappo's and Riding Mountain. However, this is not going to be a very easy task as I know the district is not free from weeds, and to put an institution there, such as we are likely to build, would mean that we would never get the weeds eradicated and we would come in for considerable criticism.

Dear Mr. Graham,

I have your note of May 25th regarding the site of the Birtle school. The Principal, Mr. Currie, reports as follows with reference to the Edmunson Farm:

"Since I have known that the deal we were trying to put thru with the Provincial Government for their Demonstration Farm had fallen through I have been looking about for a suitable site, to suggest to the Indian Department. Such a site I have found. It belongs to one Mr. T. Edmunson, it is four miles north of Birtle. The Demonstration Farm was three miles south. Mr. Edmunson has a section of land on the main Provincial Highway, Winnipeg to Edmonton. About half of the section is under cultivation, 87 acres summer fallowed last year. This is a good clean farm, well suited for mixed farming; has a fine stone house with bath; a small house for his farmer; a barn, fair condition. Dear Dr. Scott,

Just a short note to report progress. The Well Drillers are down 212 feet on the Fulton place with no prospects of water yet. There are several deep wells in that section, only one (The Demonstration Farm well) is satisfactory, and even it might be taxed beyond capacity to meet the needs of an Indian School. This well already has cost about $350.00 and by the time drilling is finished and a test made for quantity and quality, I do not expect the cost will be less than $500.00. With prospects 90% against success. And a second test, as proposed, if the present well is not a success, is as likely to be as great a failure as the present well. From the data I have obtained of the water situation in this community, my expectation or securing a suitable supply, is not strong.

In the meantime July will be gone before a site is chosen, and August will be gone before work is likely to be actually started. What chance is there of having much accomplished this year.

I have had several of our Church people see the Edmonson place, and it is all we desire. As it is for us and we are abundantly satisfied with it. We cannot understand why we are to be defeated or delayed in securing it.

We want it, the Public or Birtle and vicinity have approved of the site as being a suitable one, and the names on that petition are old Residents, farmers, merchants, professional men of all walks and ranks. Surely we are not all in error as to our choice.

One man "Cannot approve of the site." He never was on. He drove over part of the place in a car but would not go near the spot I had chosen as a site. The only reason he went near it was because he had to. You can lead a horse to water, but you can not make him drink. Because Birtle Citizens blocked his deal for the Demonstration Farm, sweet revenge, would take the school from Birtle Community. Because the Presbyterian Church Officials Opposed the, going elsewhere, sweet revenge, will keep us from getting what we want or make us wait another winter, where we are, before getting it.

The Churches interests and the Departments wishes are being blocked for REVENGE and the present action is only a show.

This is a strong condemnation, but time for dallying is past. I propose that you send someone to see the Edmonson Site and get work under way at once. Had this recommendation been agreed to the School might have been well under way. I still stick to my first suggestion, I am not afraid of any inspection the Edmonton place is put to. Its equal certainly cannot be found near Birtle.

Yours faithfully,

H.B. Currie.

REGINA, SASK. August 6th, 1929

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just had a long distance telephone call from Mr. Inspector Hamilton, who has been at Birtle on and off for the last two weeks in connection with the matter of locating water for the proposed new school at that point. It was necessary to have an officer of the Department there all the time to see that the work was properly carried on and that if water was struck it would be an ample supply. We have now drilled two holes on the farm that I hold options on, which is one mile from Birtle. Both of these holes proved to be dry, although we have gone down over 300 ft. On the same farm, however, we have located a well in a ravine, which is only 19 ft. deep. This well is in a gravel seam and I had Mr. Hamilton put a test on and he reports that he had a pump with a capacity of 900 gallons per hr. working on the well for an hour, and the 900 gals. pumped out in that length of time only reduced the water some 8". There is a depth of 5½ ft. of water in the well, and the 5" pumped out comes back within an hour, so that the well should be capable of supplying the demands of the school and more too. The question is, will it supply a lasting demand? I think it will. The only thing that would cause me to question it at all is the fact that the well is only 19 ft. deep.

I do not know that I can do anything further. Personally, I think it would be quite safe to go ahead and build here, but I want to put the matter clearly before you. There are no other farms in the district that have deep wells.

Ottawa.

Dear Dr. Scott,

This afternoon I drove out to the Scantlebury Bros. place to see how drilling in No. 2 well was progressing. I found the drilling outfit gone, and the well abandoned, after a depth of two hundred and fifty some odd feet had been reached. Soapstone had been struck, and it is said water is not usually found after the soapstone is reached.

Through the Fulton place a ravine runs, and in this ravine a shallow well is dug—18 feet deep—there is about 9 feet of water in this well now. Inspector Hamilton and Agent Lazenby had Jack and engine testing it for a pump, and as for the quality if it is good—well and as for the quantity if it is good—well to my mind it cannot be good out of the

are not good. But Mr. Edmonsons are good, and they are clean, just now is the time when weeds show up—and I was surprised just how clean this place is. And land that will produce crops as cover this place, just now, a year like this, must be soil of the very best.

I am as sure Doctor Scott, as I can be of anything, that had I two hours with you on the Edmonson place, this site question would have been settled last April—and our school would have been well under way today. As it is I fear we are doomed to spend another winter in our present quarters.

Sir,

Upon receipt of your letter of August 10th I got in touch with Mr. Graham, Indian Commissioner at Regina, and arranged to meet Inspector Hamilton of his office in Brandon on August 18th. An arranged I met Mr. Hamilton in Brandon on the evening of August 18th, and we reached Birtle the following morning. Mr. Hamilton outlined the situation they were confronted with in selecting a site for the new Indian School at Birtle. This situation is briefly as follows:

It is necessary to purchase a new site for the school and farm and 640 acres are required. Various properties were examined but the question of an adequate supply of water rather limited the choice of properties. Finally an option was secured on Section 30, Township 16, Range 27 West of the Principal Meridian. The section was suitable in every respect except for the dependability of an ample water supply. A well drilling outfit was obtained and a well drilled on the south east quarter section to a depth of 304 feet and a second well was drilled on the south west quarter section to a depth of 254 feet. Both holes passed through clay and quicksand to the soapstone and water was not obtained. A coulee runs across the south east quarter of the property and in this coulee two shallow wells had been dug years ago and a good flow of water obtained. It was reported that these wells had been found inexhaustible. Mr. Hamilton had installed a pump and engine at the deeper of these two wells and in preliminary tests it appeared as if this well might form a suitable source of supply for the new school. The option on the section expires on August 31st, and it is probable a renewal is only obtainable at considerably higher prices.

J.T. Johnson, Esq.,
Director, Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service

Ottawa, Ontario.
Before proceeding to Birtle the writer examined the records of the Manitoba Government relating to their experience in well drilling around Birtle. Their record showed that within a ten mile radius of Birtle out of many holes drilled from 200 to 300 feet, only in two was water obtained, viz. in Section 19, Township 16, Range 27. These wells were 227 feet deep and the water rose seven feet, being rather unsatisfactory results. Accordingly it was no surprise to learn of Mr. Hamilton's lack of success in deep drilling.

This coulee extends for about five miles before joining Birdtail creek and many wells have been sunk along its course. Only a few good flows of water were obtained. The well tested by Mr. Hamilton was rated as one of the best obtained. A man was then sent down into the well and he examined and found the depth of gravel to be about four feet and there was a steady stream flowing across the well, showing evidence of a spring. A study of the above test reveals that we were rather rapidly depleting the reservoir which feeds the well, and if this reservoir were in close proximity to the well the conclusion would be that the reservoir was small and incapable of supplying an adequate water supply. On the other hand should the reservoir which feeds the well be located some considerable distance away such a conclusion is not warranted for it would naturally take more time to penetrate to the immediate vicinity of the well. However, should the well be left undisturbed for several days and the water not return to its former level as found before the pumping was commenced then it can be fairly well established that the reservoir is of limited capacity and not dependable for the purpose required. Engineers of the Manitoba Government and of the City of Winnipeg, experienced in water supply studies have been consulted and the conditions existing and the results of tests outlined to them. They are of the opinion that such surface wells should be thoroughly tested before any conclusions are made as to dependability.

Upon the observations made to date it is impossible to state definitely whether this will or will not prove to be a dependable source of water supply for the proposed new school. Tests are still being carried out by Mr. Hamilton at the suggestion of the writer but it is impossible to thoroughly test a source of water supply before the expiration of the option on August 31st. The observations made to date most assuredly do not warrant the Department of Indian Affairs exercising their option on this land, but if the option can be extended one month fairly definite conclusions could be arrived at.
I also examined a well on a farm about five miles north of Birtle, a well that has been reported to be most dependable. It was found to be located in a deep coulee in a natural watercourse. It was ten feet deep and contained four feet of water, the bottom being mud with no evidence of gravel. While no pumping tests were made on this well it is apparently only a surface well.

The site for the school, tentatively selected on Section 30, Township 16, Range 27, was examined and is about 1400 feet from the well being tested. The site offers favorable opportunities for sewage disposal without any danger of contamination to the source of water supply.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have no doubt you are in receipt of a report from Mr. D. B. Gow, Assistant District Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service, Winnipeg, regarding water tests made on the two sites selected for a school at Birtle. The tests as shown in the report are quite unsatisfactory, and I am satisfied the Department would not attempt to build a school on a farm with a water supply of this kind.

Since Mr. Gow left the district Mr. Hamilton, (whom I sent down to Birtle to be present during the progress of the test for the purpose of seeing that the work was carried out properly), has located another farm six miles from Birtle, which has on it a well 110 feet deep, with a 5" hole. On Friday he operated a pump on this well for five hours, taking out 1560 gallons of water. Saturday he pumped 9 hours, taking out 3600 gallons, and also nine hours on Sunday, taking out 3500 gallons. You will note that the test covered a period of 2½ days. This looks to me like a well that would meet our requirements. I have advised Mr. Hamilton that it will not be necessary for him to remain at Birtle any longer. I question whether the Water Power Branch could do any more than we are doing. The officer who was there just carried out the test that Mr. Hamilton did,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
in fact Mr. Hamilton was looking after the test in the presence of the representative of the Water Power Branch. However, if it is your opinion that this officer should go down and make a report he should be sent there at once.

It seems to me that this supply, if it holds out, will be ample for the school requirements, and apparently there would be no difficulty in sinking another well close by which would yield the same supply to look after the stock or the school as the case might be.

I do not know if the site chosen will suit the citizens of Birtle or not, but you will note what Mr. Gow states in his report regarding the experience of the Manitoba Government in drilling for water in the Birtle district.

I may inform you that not a single minute has been lost since instructions were received at this office to have the matter attended to. Drilling operations commenced a day after I was at Birtle and continued without interruption up to a few days ago, and I have had this third test made on the farm which has been located by Mr. Hamilton six miles from Birtle. If you have any instructions that you wish carried out immediately kindly wire me.

The question of just what size of a farm the Department intends to buy for this institution has never been clearly settled. We started out by buying the Birtle Experimental Farm, which contained 320 acres, then we were looking at a section farm. The farm that we are now looking at contains three quarter sections, but whether this would be all that is necessary and all that is desirable I do not know. We can obtain a section and a quarter in this block. This land is owned by two different parties and has two complete sets of buildings. Both have wells, one of them being only fair, but sufficient to carry on the farm requirements. Mr. Hamilton thinks that all the buildings could be worked in for the use of the school. There is a splendid house which could be used for a Principal's residence, and the other house would make a good Farmer's residence. I consider that this farm at $37.50 an acre, which is the price asked, is better valued than any of the farms we have looked at for $25.00 an acre.
