Dear Sir:

On September 11th I received instructions from Dr. Archibald to inspect the farm of Mr. Edmunson at Birtle, and to report to you the kind of land and the water supply on this property. I drove to Birtle on the morning of the 12th and together with Rev. Currie and Mr. Edmunson went over the property and made borings with a four foot auger in a few places. That evening we arranged with the owner of the land to secure an engine and the necessary equipment and on the following morning we tested the well for water supply.

WATER SUPPLY.

Reporting first on the water supply I would say that the well now in use is located in a ravine. The bottom of the ravine is not more than 25 feet below the level of the surrounding parts of the farm. This well is five feet nine inches in diameter and is twelve feet six inches deep. When we commenced to pump at nine o'clock in the morning there was 42 inches of water in the well. We pumped until twelve o'clock noon. There was still twenty-seven of water and during the last hour and twenty minutes of pumping the water did not lower at all. We estimated that during the three hours we pumped between 2500 and 3000 gallons of water. Since this is one of the driest seasons experienced in many years and as this well has been in use for several years and neighbors are hauling from the well at the present time for their stock and for threshing it would seem reasonable to expect a permanent supply of water.

Regarding the quality, I may say that it has no unpleasant taste and I am by mail this morning forwarding you two...
one quart sealers. One of the containers was boiled before being used. This is marked on the sealer, in case you wish to have the bacteriological test made. The other was well washed and rinsed with the well water before being filled.

LAND.

Location: The property shown me consisted of the south half of 36-17-27 and the north half of 25-17-27. This is five miles north of the C.P.R. Depot at Birtle, and the Government highway to the northern towns is on the east side of the farm.

Surface: This is a well-drained piece of land with several shallow water courses, some emptying into the main ravine previously mentioned. There are practically no indications of sloughs although poplar trees and some willow brush are dotted over the farm. I estimated about 150 acres of bluff. Poplar trees in many of the bluffs are from 1½" to 3½" in diameter, but there are a few areas where the trees are 5" to 6" in diameter. The farmer who has considerable financial resources has only worked the land in between the bluffs so that the property presents a rather ragged appearance but both to the north and to the south of the farm the land has been kept cleared and there is no reason why once a large number of these bluffs are ploughed up that the farm would not have a good appearance.

Stones: There are about seventy acres of land, mostly on the south-east quarter section but extending a short distance into the north-east that is quite stoney in places. There are some stones in some of the water courses but for the most part the stones appear to be on the seventy acres.

SOIL.

There appeared to be about 18 inches of black sandy loam surface soil. In most places the solid clay soil appeared to be immediately below the black soil and other places we found a whitish gravelly clay between the black soil and the more solid clay below. The south-west quarter on which there appeared to be the most bluffs did not have as rich a vegetation as did the eastern and northern parts of the farm. We also observed on this quarter section a pit from which some material had been drawn to put on the roads. This
was just a small excavation. We noticed this white gravelly soil below the top subsoil. It is my opinion that the soil would be easy to work and because of being well-drained could be cultivated early in the spring. Excepting on the stoney part I believe the soil would be quite productive and would grow good crops of grain, grasses and leguminous crops.

WEEDS.

Canada Thistle is a predominating weed at the present time. The Wild Oats were also in evidence and one field appeared to have Stink Weed. We also found three patches of two or three acres each with Couch Grass and in one of the fields I noticed a number of patches of Couch Grass from six to ten feet long and three to four feet wide. There were a few plants of Sow Thistle. Given careful cultivation and proper crop rotation for a few years I believe that most of the weeds could be brought under control without too great an effort.

BUILDING SITE.

The site Mr. Currie suggested as a possible location for buildings was about three hundred yards back from the highway. There was a shallow water-run which would take the drainage from the barn yards down to the south of the farm and with a shallow ditch down the road this would empty into the main ravine in which the well is located, about eighty rods below the well. The water courses referred to practically all have their source on the farm and it is only during the time of the spring floods when there would be any water in them, and there appears to be sufficient fall so that they would drain quickly. The main objections to my mind to this property are the stoney area in the centre and the fact that there is a road allowance between the two half sections. Another objection that might be raised are the bluffs that are dotted over the farm. Many of them should be cut out and brought under cultivation so as to have square fields which could be more cheaply operated.

The well being located in a ravine might also be thought unsafe. In this connection it would appear that the walls of the well could be made of cement as the water seems to come in from the bottom. To prevent water seeping in through the surface soil a flume could be
built to carry the greater part of the spring floods away. This flume could extend higher up the ravine than the well for 200 or 300 feet and a little below the well.

I am enclosing a sketch which may help make this report a little clearer.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Superintendent.

SIR,

Upon receipt of your letter of August 10th I got in touch with Mr. Graham, Indian Commissioner at Regina, and arranged to meet Inspector Hamilton of his office in Brandon on August 18th. As arranged I met Mr. Hamilton in Brandon on the evening of August 18th and we reached Birtle the following morning. Mr. Hamilton outlined the situation they were confronted with in selecting a site for the new Indian School at Birtle. This situation is briefly as follows:

It is necessary to purchase a new site for the school and farm and 640 acres are required. Various properties were examined but the question of an adequate supply of water rather limited the choice of properties. Finally an option was secured on Section 30, Township 16, Range 27 West of the Principal Meridian. This section was suitable in every respect except for the dependability of an ample water supply. A well-drilling outfit was obtained and a well drilled on the south east quarter section to a depth of 504 feet, and a second well was drilled on the south west quarter section to a depth of 254 feet. Both holes passed through clay and quicksand to the soapstone and water was not obtained. A coulee runs across the south east quarter of the property and in this coulee two shallow wells had been dug years ago and a good flow of water obtained. It was reported that these wells had been found inexhaustible. Mr. Hamilton had installed a pump and engine at the depths of these two wells and in preliminary tests it appeared as if this well might form a suitable source of supply for the new school. The option on the section expires on August 31st and it is probable a renewal is only obtainable at considerably higher prices.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director, Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Before proceeding to Birtle the writer examined the records of the Manitoba Government relating to their experience in well drilling around Birtle. Their record showed that within a ten mile radius of Birtle out of many holes drilled the best was 300 feet; only in two was water obtained, viz., in Section 19, Township 16, Range 27. These wells were 225 feet deep and the water rose seven feet, being rather unsatisfactory results. Accordingly it was no surprise to learn of Mr. Hamilton's lack of success in deep drilling.

This coulee extends for about five miles before joining Birtail creek and many wells have been sunk along its course. Only a few good flows of water were obtained. The well tested by Mr. Hamilton was rated as one of the best obtained. It is four feet in diameter and extends about 14 feet below the ground surface, which in turn is approximately 40 feet below the general plateau level. At noon on August 19th there was about seven feet of water in the well. The writer decided to further test the well and a larger pump was secured and installed in the well. A man was then sent down into the well and he examined and found the depth of gravel to be about four feet and there was a steady stream flowing across the well, showing evidence of a spring. A study of the above test reveals that we were rather rapidly depleting the reservoir which feeds the well, and if this reservoir were in close proximity to the well the conclusion would be that the reservoir was small and incapable of supplying an adequate water supply. On the other hand should the reservoir which feeds the well be located some considerable distance away such a conclusion is not warranted. As it would naturally take more time to penetrate to the immediate vicinity of the well. However should the well be left undisturbed for several days after the water not return to its former level and found before the pumping was commenced then it can be fairly well established that the reservoir is of limited capacity and not dependable for the purpose required. Engineers of the Manitoba Government and of the City of Winnipeg, experienced in water supply studies have been consulted and the conditions existing and the results of tests outlined to them. They are of the opinion that such surface wells should be thoroughly tested before any conclusions are made as to dependability.

Upon the observations made to date it is impossible to state definitely whether this will or will not prove to be a dependable source of water supply for the proposed new school. Tests are still being carried out by Mr. Hamilton at the suggestion of the writer but it is impossible to thoroughly test this source of water supply before the expiration of the option on August 31st. The observations made to date most assuredly do not warrant the Department of Indian Affairs exercising their option on this land, but if the option can be extended one month fairly definite conclusions could be arrived at.
I also examined a well on a farm about five miles north of Birtle, a well that has been reported to be most dependable. It was found to be located in a deep coulee in a natural watercourse. It was ten feet deep and contained four feet of water, the bottom being mud with no evidence of gravel. While no pumping tests were made on this well it is apparently only a surface well.

The site for the school, tentatively selected on Section 30, Township 16, Range 57, was examined and is about 1400 feet from the well being tested. The site offers favorable opportunities for sewage disposal without any danger of contamination to the source of water supply.

Birtle, Man. 16 Sept. 1929

Dear Mr. Scott,

Last Thursday and Friday Mr. Penline, Superintendent of the Brandon Experimental Farm came in to inspect the Edmonson place. You will probably have his report by the time you receive this. I have no idea what that report will be, but I trust it is such that you will be led to give a favorable report consideration to the Edmonson property as the site for our new school. One thing I can say Mr. Penline gave the place a very careful inspection. Thursday afternoon we drove the place first just to get an idea, then we went on foot and made various tests as to surface soil, sub soil and etc. The whole of which I expect you will get in detail.

I am convinced a favorable impression remained in Mr. Penline's mind, as
to the building site, drainage and water. We had a pump - worked by gas engine - pumping three hours, and pumped over 2600 gallons. In the beginning the water in the well went down a little, but after pumping two hours we got down in the well, to the place where it was coming in as fast as we could pump it out. For the last hour pumping - we did not lower the water in the well, if anything it gained on us, and I am of the opinion we could have pumped indefinitely without lowering the water in the well. It acted just as Mr Edmonson has always told me it would do. Its standing up as it did under this test, in a year like this, when many wells are dry and 90% of the sloughs are dry and the river lower than the oldest resident ever remembers seeing it; so in itself, I think, ample to conclude we will never be short of water. After pumping three hours we went to lunch. On our return after lunch, in 1 hr and 20 min., the water in the well was back to within 8 inches, where it was in the morning before we began to pump.
The farm itself is only fair— but is good enough to make a profitable farm—and under good farming can be improved 100% in five years. The fencing on it is poor barb wire. It should be re-fenced with woven wire, for stock and sheep farming.

It is too late for doing much this year, but this is my recommendation. If Mr. Andrews' report is favorable, buy Mr. Edmonson's place at once, for the following reasons. First, the contract can yet be let this fall; the contractor may get basement excavated and get his material on the ground during winter for an early start in spring—and will most probably have the building ready for use by 15 Aug 1930 on return of pupils from summer vacation.

My second reason is, I do not know what to do with my stock this winter, my stables are tumbling down and are too small at any rate, I cannot get all my present stock inside—I now have 8 horses and...
Birtle, Man.

I have 36 head of cattle. The cattle consist of 10 calves which will be killed soon, 3 grade cows, and one Pure Breed Dual Shorthorn Bull - bought from Mr Alexander MacLaren Buckingham, Zoe. 18 Pure Breed Shorthorn milking cows; 4 Pure Breed 2yr old heifers that will freshen before Christmas. 13 Pure Breed females under 2 years. 4 Bull calves, 3 for sale; to be retained to replace my present sire. This totals 33 Pure Breed Dual Shorthorns and 4 Grades.

If I get rid of the 4 grades, as I intend, there is 4 calves to be born in 1929 to take their place. My Shorthorn herd is easily worth $4000.00.

I do not wish to dispose of my Shorthorns simply because I am crowded for room. If you buy the Edmonton place soon, the buildings on it, while not good will give us the necessary accommodation for this winter.

Again there is a feed problem for this season. The Edmonton place has ample good oat straw that should go with the place and will solve feed problem.

The water submitted for examination from the Birtle School site was in two jars, one of which was stated to be sterilized and the other rinsed with the water itself. The sterilized jar shows contamination in a moderate degree and the unsterilized one in a marked degree. Neither of these samples of water would be suitable for drinking purposes without treatment.

A test of this sort is of very little value by itself. If the well is open it is subject to contamination which would not occur if it were closed and protected. If the surroundings were bad the water would be polluted, but might be rendered safe by cleaning up the ground near the well removing possible manure piles etc. There is no information on these points, and it is therefore impossible to say whether the well, as distinct from the samples, is a safe well or not.

The test for hardness indicates that the water is soft and should be suitable for boiler use as water goes in the west.

E.L. Stone, M.B.
Director of Medical Services

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of August 31st requesting that a report be prepared on the Edmonson farm near Birtle as a satisfactory site for the new Indian School.

While at Birtle on August 21st and at the request of Mr. Gresham, Indian Commissioner at Regina, I drove out to the Edmonson farm and examined the well that serves as the water supply for the farm. Mr. Edmonson's farm is located about 5½ miles in a northerly direction from Birtle. No examination was made for a satisfactory site for the school on this property.

A rather deep coulee runs through the farm and along the bottom of this coulee I noticed two or three wells that were apparently abandoned and not in use. The well that is now the source of water supply for the farm is located in the bottom of the coulee and is in the path of a natural water course during the spring break-up. REPORT ON WATER SUPPLY FOR PROPOSED INDIAN SCHOOL AT BIRTLE, MANITOBA.

SIR:

In accordance with the instructions contained in your letter of September 6th I got in touch with Commissioner Graham of Regina and learned that Mr. P. G. Lazenby, Indian Agent at Birtle, would be at hand to show me the location of the farm now being considered a suitable site for the Birtle Indian School. Arriving in Birtle on September 30th I accompanied Mr. Lazenby on an inspection of the well on the property and also the suggested location of the school building. Arrangements had previously been made for Mr. Lazenby to have a gasoline engine set up in readiness to pump the well. The well was subjected to pumping tests on October 1st and 2nd, and considerable data were gathered as to the conditions met with in drilling the well.

This well is located on the S.W. ¼, Sec. 7, Tp. 17, Rge. 25, West of the Principal Meridian, the property of Mr. Butcher. It is about four miles east and one mile north of the town of Birtle. The well was drilled in December, 1928, to a depth of approximately 111 feet. Blue clay was encountered to a depth of 94 feet, the remaining 18 feet being in slate or shale. Water was obtained in considerable volume and drilling was discontinued. A five-inch casing extends from the surface down into the shaft, and the well is fitted with a windmill-driven pump that extends down 69 feet from the top of the casing. The pump pipe line is ½ inch diameter and the cylinder is located approximately 68 feet below the surface. The well is utilized to supply water for the ordinary needs of the farm of 480 acres. On the morning of October 1st the water stood 22 feet below the top of the casing so that there was about 88 feet of water in the well and the water surface was about 45 feet above the cylinder. The well was pumped steadily that day from 8:50 a.m. until 3:30 p.m., when the pump broke down and repairs had to be made. The day's results are tabulated below:

The pumping equipment of the well is inadequate to make a square pumping test. There was 40 feet of water in the well below the pump and it is altogether likely that with a pump extending to the bottom of the well the rate of discharge would have been considerably increased when pumping against inflow. The five-inch casing permits of much larger pumping equipment but of course the present installation is quite ample for ordinary farm needs.

The favorable features about this well are that it is not a shallow surface well, is free from the liability of contamination, extends some 17 feet into shale and the reservoir pressure is sufficient to raise the water some 90 feet in the casing. The water level returns to this same level after moderate pumping showing that there has been no
lessening of the pressure from the underground reservoir. No definite conclusions as to the dependability of this well can be arrived at from the results of this test, but the writer is of the opinion that the well is adequate to supply the needs of the Indian School.

A sample of the water from this well was taken and submitted for analysis to the Bacteriological Laboratory, Department of Health and Public Welfare of the Province of Manitoba. Their report shows the water to be free from contamination and one of the best waters submitted to them for years.

While no definite site has been considered for the proposed school on this property, there is a very favorable site available within 300 feet of the well and this site permits of perfect drainage conditions.

An examination of the well showed that about 10 feet of clay overlaid the gravel and the well penetrated the gravel only two feet. From the results of the pumping test I am of the opinion that this well will provide an ample water supply for the proposed Indian School. Dear Mr. Graham:

While looking after share of crops from our farms near Birtle this fall I heard that your department was meditating the establishment of an Indian Agricultural College in the Birtle district and looking for a good site (so that Indian students would forget about gathering senica root digging out wolves for a living soon as leaving old style schools.) I also heard that your investigators favored SW¼ 7-17-25 owned by Mr. Fred Butcher owing to superior quality of his land, abundance of the best kind of water in both a deep well also a shallow well dug into the quicksand and water, also a very fine, well-sheltered building site for a large set of buildings adjoining the good buildings now on this place with splendid drainage for both buildings and lands, etc. Hence this is to draw your attention to E½ 7-17-25 which adjoins Mr. Fred Butcher's land on two sides about 230 acres of which is now under cultivation, besides 10 or 12 acres of good hay, some 62 acres of which is 1929 summerfallow ready for 1930 crop. The whole half section is arable but I think it would be a pity to destroy many of the fine poplar bluffs that has been nursed for say 30 years.

Clear Torrence title and all taxes paid to date. I enclose a township map with rough pencilled diagrams featuring topography and descriptions of E½ 7-17-25, Man., and adjoining lands, trusting that it may help to give your department a better idea of these lands. You may remember that these farms had the reputation of being the most productive and richest land in the Birtle district, and still holds this up. If your department is still interested in such a location I take the liberty of submitting E½ 7-17-25 for sale (along with Mr. Fred Butcher's lands) for your purposes and if you are interested in this I would gladly give you farther information about it at your request.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Irving C. Nelson.
